comments.comment: There is a lacuna concerning two lines on the left side, which can be evaluated to ca. 10 akṣaras for the first and ca. 12 akṣaras for the second one. In general, many punctuation signs between pādas are not spelled, and the graphemes are not used consistently.

One can still read 〈ty〉 belonging to the left part of a ligatura: it can most probably be restored as (mar)ty(āṃ) being the last word of pāda 41c. At the end of this lacuna one may restore (onol)m(eṃ) translating Skt. martyāṃ.

The reading kakraupaṣaṃ is certain, but we expect the nom.pl.masc. kakraupaṣ parallel to preceding yamoṣ, cf. Skt. samāhitā(ḥ). One is led to assume that this mistake is due to copying of a former spelling kakraupaṣ \•.

As translation of Skt. māraṃ in 42a one finds TB maraṃ, which cannot simply be taken as a mistake. This form should be understood as the oblique singular of TB mār being the regular match of Skt. māra-. Actually, the most common Tocharian expression is TB mār-ñäkte (TA mār-ñkät). We do find the expected oblique singular TB māräṃ in B 30 b 2. A first possibility would be to take TB maraṃ as analogical of the regular gen.sg. marántse ‹ *mārä’ntse (). Maybe a better alternative would be to assume that this scribe (school) has chosen to inflect TB mār according to the productive pattern of TB sāṃ ‘enemy’, obl.sg. sanáṃ ‹ *sānä’ṃ (= class 5.3. in TEB).
After ṣa[māni] there is space for a punctuation dot as compared with the preceding lines.

The verbal noun meaning ‘death’ here is srūkalle, whereas we find the expected form srūkalyñe in line a 1. It is obvious that srūkalle is a rhyming form with preceding cmelle ‘birth’, which is also used before in line a3 translating Skt. jāti-. Already in the classical language there was confusion between the verbal abstract in -l(y)ñe and the substantivized gerund in -lle with palatalized liquid. Actually, for ‘birth’ the language had the verbal abstract cmel(y)ñe, which would be perfectly parallel to srūkalyñe. Therefore, it seems that the scribe had at his disposal two variants meaning approximately the same. He may have chosen the variant in lle to make a rhyme in the sequence cmelle srūkallentse (b1) while ktsaitsäññe srūkalyñe also is some kind of rhyme. In addition, he uses srūkalyñe to translate Skt. mṛtyu- (41d), while using srūkalle to translate Skt. maraṇa- (42d). One may thus say that the choice between the two variants was stylistically motivated.
One has yśelme (= nominative) instead of the vocative yśelma found in the next line. Note that in most declination classes vocative and nominative have the same form.
The scribe has written mūlam \ • in order to represent the correct accusative singular ending in -m, while the Sanskrit text has the sandhi form mūlaṃ.
The form tänmastär is wrong for the expected 2.sg.mid. tänmastar as translating Skt. jāyase. Note that the 3.sg. middle was present below in the translation of pāda 2a.

At the beginning of the line the traces of the first akṣara are compatible with a tentative reading 〈mā〉, which would translate Skt. na at the beginning of pāda 1c. In the lacuna one may restore (mā ci plāskau). This makes four syllables and the further addition of the eight syllables of the Sanskrit pāda 1d will fill the lacuna exactly. The last word has to be restored as tä(nmastär).

comments.comment: Note that the iterative adverb Skt. tat tat (11d) is translated by the corresponding TB adverb and with the emphatic particle -k in order to render the expressive force of the repetition (and not simply by tu tu).
One should restore (kuce) kuce translating Skt. yad yaj jahāti kāmānāṃ (11c).

The verbal form ending with -tär ought to be restored as riñiträ. The translation of the pāda 12b Skt. sarvakāmāṃ parityajet was certainly po yśelmeṃ päst riñiträ. The correct Sanskrit form should be sarvakāmaparityāgī (12c). sukha at the end of the line is the beginning of Skt. sukham edhate (12d).

Note that the Sanskrit text has the reading anusaraṃ in all manuscripts. The spelling -an\ is consistent with the spelling -am\ met in other instances in this same manuscript. At the end of the line na is the first word of the pāda 13a. Very tentatively one can interpret the remains of the akṣaras at the beginning of the line as reflecting a 3.sg.mid. verbal form matching Skt. edhate (12d), possibly (yän)[m](ās)[tä]r ‘he obtains’.
The Sanskrit aorist adhi-agāt at the end of 13b is literary translated by the preterite yonmasa even though (as is clear from the context) the Sanskrit form has a gnomic value.
At the end of the line tu ought to be completed to tumeṃ matching Skt. tataḥ at the beginning of pāda 13c.
At the end of the line one should restore the perlative singular aiśamñesa translating Skt. prajñayā (13d).
The complete Sanskrit pāda 14b is: na hi kāmair vitṛpyate.

comments.comment: The text has the late/colloquial forms piś-yikne for piś-yäkne (a1, a6) and araṃśne for arañcne (a6).
For a detailed commentary and discussion of Sanskrit parallels, see in general .

The leaf consists of two fragments that make no joint (contrary to the plates in ). The smaller left one has the measure 3,9 x 8,5, the larger one 24,1 x 8,8; the size of the whole manuscript is known by the following leaves and . The left margin is lost here.

The reading piśpikne by Filliozat is wrong, so there is no word piśpik, pace . Instead we have piś-yikne, a colloquial form of piś-yäkne 'of five sorts'. According to the Sanskrit text, the pain in question concerns five body parts, but the Tocharian translator forgot the last term Skt. stana- 'breast, nipple' or maybe he included it in the translation of Skt. hṛdaya- 'heart'.
In raṇḍabilvā the final long vowel ā has been added by another hand; the form pāṣāṇabhe has likewise been corrected to pāṣāṇabhi.
°gandhābhi has been corrected into °gandhā«ṣ»i by another hand.

line.tr: Sanskrit 92. A decoction cooked with Terminalia chebula has to be combined with the [following] powder: ten grains of Croton polyandrum [and] five half grains of Piper longum [and] salt. It has to be given

as a purgative. Mixed with ricinus oil [it is] a infallible destroyer of all diseases. These [following ingredients] precisely have to be made into nasal injection: syrup [has to be mixed] with ginger,
rock salt has to be mixed with syrup [and] Piper longum in the nostrils. The pain [is] as follows: [one is] mute, paralyzed; [it is] in the neck [and] in the jaw, in the arm, in the head,
in both eyes, in the throat, in the ear; the back [is] sick. [It] has to be blown into the nostrils. [It is] good for everything. 92. Sanskrit
Sanskrit 93. Sesame oil has to be cooked together with Sida cordifolia [and] with sandal, which has to be made into a paste [first]. [It] has to be mixed with milk

[and] with the three milk products [and] with fermented vinegar. [It] has to be cooked separetly together with Asparagus racemosus. [This] has to be made into an oily enema. [It is] a killer of wind [disease]. 93. Sanskrit
Sanskrit 94. With
Vanda roxburghii, the fruit of Randia dumetorum, the three myrobalan, Tinospora cordifolia, twice [the five] roots, Sida cordifolia, meat broth, sesame oil, salt,
honey, syrup, sugar lump, aneth, the heart of the fruit of Aegle marmelos, Saussurea lappa, Piper longum, Acorus calamus, sour gruel, cow urine or milk, a nasal injection
[or] an enema has to be made. In case [of all] diseases of wind [it is] good. [If] one takes [it] with broth, [it is] good as well. Sanskrit

line.tr: Sanskrit 112. Fatigue,

[excessive] sweating, inflammation, reddening, oral malodor, moisture, bad digestion, disorder of the body fluids, delirious speech, fainting, dizziness [and] jaundice [lit. being yellow] [are] the symptoms of bile [diseases],
say the wise ones. 112. Sanskrit
Sanskrit 113. Paleness, [feeling of] coldness, [feeling of] heaviness, itching, greasiness of the body, steadiness,

infection of the respiratory tract, rejection [of mucus] and accumulation [of mucus], and also impairment of reaction [lit. acting slowly], [these are] the symptoms of phlegma [diseases], said the wise ones. 113. Sanskrit
Sanskrit And these

symptoms induced by that [= the preceding three elements] [belong] even to all diseases which have the same name. Some other difference does exist for these ones because of which they receive [lit. go to, shift to] a [specific] name and another [cure]. 114.
Sanskrit 115
Exhaustion, sleepiness, non-purity of the heart, the development of vicious elements, the absence of hunger, the heaviness of belly,
disgust, drowsiness, they [the wise ones] say that the [preceding] disease is bound with the absence of digestion,— and also the [excessive] urge to urinate. 115. Sanskrit
Sanskrit The wind [disease is cured]
by fasting [lit. food to be rejected], by sesame oil, by salty [or] sweet food [and] drinks; the bile [disease is cured] exactly in the same way (by) sweet [or] bitter decoctions.

comments.comment: The leaf number is written in the string hole space.

The Tocharian translation does not correspond to the Sanskrit text, which is corrupt. The original passage refers to the three elements wind, bile, and phlegma that induce diseases. Each disease has an individual proper name and in addition a second name referring to the prevalence of symptoms that are characteristic of one of the three elements like Skt. vātaja- 'generated from wind'; see . The Tocharian text, however, by itself transports the genuine sense, so that one may surmise it reflects an oral commentary transmitted independently of the written transmission.
Above the last akṣara of mamauñempa one sees a dot, which is a blotch rather than an anusvāra.

Zugleich vergeht [wtl. setzt sich] das Leiden.
At the same time, suffering passes [lit. sets itself (to rest)]
roots of Tribulus terrestris, [two varieties of] Boerhaavia diffusa L., ricinus – the infusion is to be cooked either with water or with milk [and] this [is] to be poured over [it]; either oil
or sesame oil [is] to be poured over [it] – as a remedy against abscess. Barley flour, aneth and porridge [are] to be cooked, together with oil

[it] has to be poured over [it] as a remedy against inflammation and sickness. In case of the [two kinds of] wounds [and in case of a] boil, [this is] a remedy against abscess. But now I will tell the remedy

against the fourth day fever. Trigonella foenum graecum L., the grain of Holarrhena antidysenterica, Helleborus niger, Trigonella corniculata, Aconitum heterophyllum, Acorus calamus, cardamoms:

comments.comment: The text has some late features: sātke for sāṃtke (several times); witsakaṃ (a5); aṅkainsa for aṅkaintsa (b5).
A complete leaf; the leaf number is written inside the string hole space.
uppāl\•ṣṣana: Note the virāma stroke separating the adjective suffix.

Filliozat read vitsakabij, but the manuscript clearly has vatsakabij, unless one assumes that the vowel had been completely erased (which does not seem very likely given the good preservation of the fragment).
One has to read motämpa not mautämpa (the blotch above the sign is not a correction mark).
The correct reading is [k]aṅko, because the third blotch upon the sign cannot belong to an 〈au〉 to be judged by other clear instances of 〈au〉 in the same manuscript.

In the lacuna the last akṣara l·e is quite certain; before one may see a trace of an e-vowel, so that a restoration (y)[o](ka)l(l)[e] is possible. If this is correct, we expect a perlative before the gerund. One can read kapo, kaṣo, or kapho. A kapo(tsa) may be a borrowing of Skt. kāpota- 'antimony, natron'. As for [tsak]\, the first sign is very unclear while the k is quite certain.

to (staunch) [it] perfectly. Caesalpina sappan, aneth, Symplocos racemosa, collyrium, yellow arsenic: [this is to be used] with blood to staunch [it] perfectly. Bandages (??) (have to be made) ...

comments.comment: An almost complete leaf, about 5 to 6 akṣaras are missing on the right margin. The leaf number is written inside the string hole space, which is rather [7]5 and not 55 (as per Filliozat). This may be a typo in .
ṣotarnma seems to be a late plural form of ṣotri 'mark' (instead of ṣotruna).

A separation tāk okne is also possible, but not very likely. Both forms would be hapax; to be sure, kok may be interpreted as a wrong Sanskritization of a Prakrit form from Skt. kotha- ‘sore, gangrene' or 'affliction of the eye' (cf. ).
One has to read ṣili, which ought to be a mistake for pili. Sieg's correction of pili into pile is speculative; one can accept pili as nom. plural and construct it with yāmoṣ in a subordinate clause.
Note the virāma sign separating the case suffix in śakkār\•mpa.
śabaraloträ is a single word, which has been wrongly separated by a dot.
The remains of the last akṣara permit a reading kaṭpa(l)\ or kaṭpa(ñ)\. The closest Sanskrit word would be khaṭvā- 'kind of bandage', the borrowing of which would give the nom.pl.
Note saitsi for saintsi.
The reading śvakate is superior to ścakate and allows a restoration (a)śvakate to be connected with Skt. aśvagandha- 'Withania somnifera' (otherwise attested by the form TB aśvakānt).

kampāsäṣṣe cannot simply mean 'cotton'; the form kampās in THT 337 a 4 is a mistake for kampāl warranted by the parallel text PK AS 18A and note that TA kappās (via Middle Indic kappāsa- from Skt. karpāsa ‘cotton' refers to the cotton plant rather that the material. On the other hand, the woven cotton is called kenek, TA kanak.

lope is rather a borrowing from Skt. lopa-, which can have the meaning 'hurting, breaking, violation' than a late form of a Tocharian abstract laupe from lup- 'to smear'. Consequently, terwe is rather the direct object (and not an adverb, as supposed by Sieg), whis is proven by the object construction with -ne in the parallel passage in b2. It may refer to a part of the skin (?). interprets the form as 'kind of snake' and translates b2 "I will speak now of a salve, a medicine for whom the terwe bites", but this does not work syntactically.

Instead of naṣṣū one has to read kaṣṣu. The following akṣara before the l\ is hardly a ‹ba›, and it cannot be ‹bā› in the first place, because the long ā-vowel would be written to the right and not on top of the sign. pil can be Skt. bilva- 'Aegle marmelos fruit'.
po is rather the end of an ingredient, and not the word po 'all'.
The process of crushing has apparently to be done by a young girl before her maturation, and if an adult woman has to do it, one has to make sure that she is devoid of menstrual blood.
The reading sal [ṣa]rn[e] by Sieg is impossible, the manuscript has salturna of unknown meaning.

line.tr: May I have (trust thorough)ly [and] always in the good (or) bad act. [23b] May I seize the shame [and] modesty [that is] the one praised by the wise ones [and that is] dear to the good ones. [23c] May I always have the consciousness grown in moral behavior [and]

directed at the Law for long. 23. Through the writing of this excellent Śramaṇavarga may I recognize the thirst as a torment (kleśa). [24a] Again may I recognize the blame in the cauldron consisting in the clinging to let turn the birth[cycle]. [24b]
In connection with monkhood may I be able to tame the spirit [and] to make it pure. [24c] May I seize firmly [and] completely the rules pertaining to moral behavior; may my zeal not recede. 24.
Möchte ich die Richtlinien des sittlichen Verhaltens insgesamt fest erfassen; möchte mein Eifer nicht nachlassen!
May I grasp the rules of moral behaviour firmly; may my zeal never relent!
Das höchste [Ziel ist] das Gesetz, würdig [bzw. das Gesetz als das höchste [Ziel ist] würdig], von den drei Welten auf den Scheitel genommen zu werden [bzw. auf dem Scheitel getragen zu werden].
The highest [goal is] the law, worthy [or: the law as the highest [goal is] worthy] of being taken onto the crown of the head by the three worlds [or: of being worn on the crown of the head].

The Law as the supreme goal [is] worthy of being taken on the top of the three worlds. [25a] Through the writing of the excellent sun of the Mārgavarga may this path remain for a long time. [25b] In this way indeed may I make manifest the excellent eightfold
Durch das Schreiben der vortrefflichen Mārgavarga-Sonne möge dieser Pfad lange bestehen! Auf ebendiese Weise möchte ich den achtgliedrigen edlen Pfad [als] besten offenbar machen!
By writing the excellent Mārgavarga-sun, may this path persist [for] long! In exactly the same manner, may I make visible the eight-part noble path!

noble path. [25c] Through the seeing of the four truths may all obtain the pure eyes of wisdom. 25. I have written the Satkāravarga [understanding] this gain [and] pride (= Skt. lābha-satkāra-) as the e(nemy) of all the virtues. [26a]

He [= the enemy] tears out the skin of moral behavior [and] he cuts into small pieces the whole meat of wisdom. [26b] He breaks the bones of the energy [and] he cooks the marrow of meditation completely. [26c] Like the snake with sharp venom, even more than that,

may I avoid gain [and] pride. 26. Through the writing of the Drohavarga may my wish come true in the circle of all births. [27a] May I not feel anger towards an evil person, even an angry one, and even less
Durch das Schreiben des Drohavarga möge mir der Wunsch im Kreislauf aller Geburten in Erfüllung gehen: ...
By writing the Drohavarga, [this] wish may be fulfilled for me in the circle of all births: ...

towards good people. [27b] Even towards a murderous enemy may hate [and] enmity not reside in me at all [and] may I abandon the sin. [27c] May I not have a meeting with an ignorant one [and] may I come together with good people.
Mit einem Unwissenden möge mir nicht Zusammenkommen sein. Mit Guten möchte ich zusammenkommen!
With an ignorant one, may there be no meeting for me. May I meet with good ones!

27 Through the writing of the Smṛtivarga, this foundation of all virtues, may my wish come true. [28a] By consciousness directed towards the body may I understand all qualities [= dharma], each by its own mark. [28b] May I always
Durch das Schreiben des Smṛtivarga, dieser Grundlage aller Tugenden, möge mir der Wunsch in Erfüllung gehen: ...
By writing the Smṛtivarga, this foundation of all virtues, [this] wish may be fulfilled for me: ...

awake the good awakening having seized in the heart the three excellent jewels. [28c] May I not forget the observance, the wisdom, the meditation, without making harm. 28 (I have written) the Prakīrṇakavarga ...

comments.comment: The text has some colloquial spellings: cimpim for cämpim in a3, araṃśne for arañcne in b5, and degemination in śaiṣentso (a4) and ompalskoñe (b5). Whether sälyeṃno in a3 shows colloquial monophthongization or is simply an error for sälyaiṃno is difficult to judge. Since the text is metrical, forms with o mobile (or even preserved -ä as in wṣi-ñä in b 3) are often used.

The text has interesting spellings of virāma position: sometimes one has double marking with virama stroke and dot (e.g., pālaṣ[ä]\• in a 1); the chapter names xy-varga- > xy-vārgä borrowed from Sanskrit are never written with virama (even if the syllable is not counting metrically), which fits a more general writing habit also found in prose texts (cf. ). We also have virāma marking of the akālk-type with a small stroke between the la and the lower ka.
The meter is 4 x 18 (7/7/4).
A complete leaf. It contains the Udānastotra in the longer version where the stanzas of the text proper are numbered 16 - 46 instead of 10 - 40.

Judging by the spelling (which is confirmed by both parallel texts), ykū-ime can only be a compound, to be more precise a pseudo-bahuvrihi 'having the consciousness of arriving'; it seems to be based on Skt. nityaṃ dharmagatā smṛtiḥ "always reflecting upon the Law" (attested in Uv. 15.10d and 13d) by a literal transposition of °gata- 'arriving' with the PPt yku ‘gone'.
The meter requires an additional syllable, which is the pronoun cau, judging from the parallel b5. Note the different version śīlne ausu in the parallel.
Pace Lévi and Thomas, one has to read [l](·)[k](·)[ñ](·) based on an autopsy of the original.

Pace Lévi and Thomas, one has to read [ai]sene based on an autopsy of the original. Note the variant verb fom karstoym in the parallel texts b 5 and b 6. Actually, both verbs make acceptable sense, but one should note that karsoym is effectivley attested in the next pāda.
At the end of the line there seems to be not enough space for the expected double dots.
In ynāmñe the second ligatura shows some kind of anusvāra sign above the ña, but ynāmñeṃ makes no sense.

Pace Lévi and Thomas, one has to read miyaṣly(·)e : [28] (–)[k]ī[rṇ](·) based on an autopsy of the original. There are no traces of ä-dots over the ya in miyaṣly(ñ)e. The form (although from the kausativ paradim) preserves A-character (cf. ).

line.tr: In [the tune] Vilumpagati: I have written with a great wish the excellent Udānavarga provided with meaning [and] [literary] form, which chases away the diseases of the passions, the good jewel of the Law, the excellent one, that has been bought by the dear lives of the omniscents as numerous as the grains of sand of the Ganges. May the darkness of ignorance of [the beings] of the five births disappear through this deed! 1. Having heard the great bas(kets) [i.e., the canonical writings] that
(ex)ist through wonder, since for each single śloka you [the Buddha] have given by thousands [your] heads to be cut off, [and] to flay your skin from the body,

your energy did not wane to make flow [your] blood, [and your] marrow. O lord, by (sell)ing y(ourself) blood overflowed out from eighty thousand pores. 2. For the sake of the Law may I abandon [as lightly] as grass my head [and] this living!
May I become unconcerned [and] may I not care about life, (senses), [and] (bo)dies! May I obtain the support of awareness! May the companion of firmness not leave me! With the wish for omniscience
I myself went the way (of the) Law with(out stopping). 3. May my heart turn into a diamond in order to endure my own sufferings, may my strenght increase! May my heart become overwhelmed (?), [and]

permeated with constant compassion facing the (su)ffering (of the beings)! If for the sake of the beings of the five births I were even be reborn in the Avīci [hell], may my spiritual strength increase! (May I remain?) without turning back
from the omniscience! 4. May I obtain the medicine [and] may I grant the ambrosia of the Law to the [beings] of the five births! May my spirit be firm, may it not (make) any difference [to have]
Möchte ich den Gesetzesnektar (zu trinken) erlangen [und ihn] den Fünfgeburtenwesen wachsen lassen!
May I gain the nectar of the law (as drink) [and may] I let it grow [for/in] the beings of the five incarnations!

a son among enemies. With the Law may my spirit not obtain pleasure (in evil) even for the measure of an instant! May I not miss the feast of the omniscience and may I obtain the departure from the house! 5

The fruit of even a single stanza ... may become concrete for me now! And through this merit of mine may all the beings of the five births turn away from Lawlessness! (May) the 108 pa(ssions be eliminated!)

comments.comment: . took as basis for his edition of S 8 a manuscript with the expedition number , which is now lost. But a first draft of the transcription of 1933 is preserved, and it allows the completion of some passages. We here basically edit M 500.3, which was edited by Lévi as a supplement of S 8, but without the fragment PK NS 120. under "S 8" actually edited only the supplement without giving the actual press mark and without the joint either. To be sure, the lost ms. is not a complete parallel but a slighty different version and has one additional stanza. According to the numbering, contained the end of the Udānastotra (consisting of 31 stanzas) and the conclusion. On the other hand, M 500.3+PK NS 120 belongs to a second recension, which uses almost the same stanzas of the conclusion for the introduction. For this reason, M 500.1 starts numbering the stanzas of the conclusion with "41", while this one that is M 500.3 starts with "1". The additional stanza of is no. 43, which would be between "2" and "3" in the M 500.3+PK NS 120 recension. For the restoration of the whole Udānastotra, see . See also the note in about the existance of two Tocharian Udānastotra recensions.
The introduction in this fragment differs from the one attested in . Accordingly, this may be the long introduction in 15 stanzas.
Completed to the left by PK NS 120 (see ), which gives a complete leaf. There is a perfect joint between the fragments in lines 3 after the string hole.
The restoration (poyśin)ta(ṃ)ts is warranted by the parallel version M 500.1 a 4.
paikāmai is complete in the parallel M 500.1 a 5. The restoration of ne(sa)l(le)ṃ is based on the comparison with Lévi's reading for M 500.1 a 5.
The restoration (mrestī)we is warranted due to the attestation of mr in M 500.1 b 1.

The expected formulation would be keś ... taccimar 'may I (not) take into account'; it does not seem possible to restore it inside the lacuna because keś would stand in the middle of a series of objects. The restoration indrinta is further warranted by the parallel M 500.1 b4.

yeymä is written without virāma, but it counts for one syllable according to the meter. Instead of the imperfect yeym, the parallel M 500.1 b 5 has the present yam. The existance of the two versions may be the reason for the blunder of the scribe. The original text ought to have had the present with future value. Probably it has been accomodated to the optative context by using the final sequence -ym. Actually, the standard imperfect form is yaim.

The restoration mauki is certain due to M 500.1 b 5. Further, Lévi edited mauki – – ·ai ·ai·ṣṣe. Since this is one syllable too many, it is likely that Lévi read ai ·ai· in the lost manuscript and edited ṣṣ(·) from this one. Accordingly, one has to restore pelaikneṣṣai.

We read mlamo instead of mlamau because the latter does not seem to be a correct PPt of any root (cf. .). On the other hand, mlamo could be a correct agent noun in -mo of any root mäl-. With respect to the context, a meanig like 'overwhelmed' would make sense, and would make the form a derivative of in the sense of "being overpowered by emotion".
One may restore ñiś stamoym "may I remain".

The sense here must be sought in an allusion to Buddhist legends such as the Araṇemi- or the Viśvantara-Jātaka, where a Bodhisattva gives away his own son to enemies in order to accomplish his vow to Buddhahood.

line.tr: ... This human life, [if] it is a state of bliss, (the cause) of it [is] (from) the sense of language [lit. tongue] ... (5.)
... through the wish concerning the establishment of the good Law (for the) benfit of the beings ...
... through the fruit (of this deed) may the ignorance of [the beings] of the five births disappear! 6. ...
May I myself never tell (evi)l speech of four sorts! (May I not) ... my self ...
May I not praise the Lawlessness in all the births! 7. What [is] the speech [called] Buddhavacana, Sū(tra, Vinaya, Abhidharma) ... May I seize ...
what (has been) said or what has been praised at the first lecture [lit. hearing] with meaning and literary form (according) to the proper manner. ...
... may I touch ... 8. What I have written for myself [or] what [I have written] in order to teach others, (both?) [are] (with) [good] reason. ...
May (I) myself not forget the three excellent jewels in the hearts of the five births!
I have written (the Anityavarga): Through the fruit of this deed, may this wish be fulfilled! ...
... without self may I understand the five elements [= skandhas] as unper(manent). ... 10.
Through (the writing) of the Kāmavarga may I understand always the defect of the desires (in) all births! ... (Through the Tṛṣṇāvarga may)
thirst [and] hunger not see me enraged in the whole Saṃsāra! ...

comments.comment: This leaf belongs to a manuscript with a short introduction of nine stanzas, because with the long introduction the Udānastotra proper beginns with no. 16. Note that the stanzas 11 and 12 each cover two chapters instead of one as usual. This version of the introduction is different from the one in .
Left part of a leaf with the string hole preserved.

The striking second ī of indrī speaks for a form accented on the second syllable, the best candidate seems to be the ablative according to the synchronic accent rule. The first long ī is due to sandhi. The ablative in this context expresses the cause.
The four types of evil speech are lying, defamation, harsh speech and senseless talk. They belong to the ten akuśalakarmapatha- "the evil ways of conduct".
Concerning the traditional list of the parts of the Buddhist canon, see for example a 4.
akālk has double virāma writing of the akālk-type.

A restitution tṛṣṇāvārg paikāmai would not fit the following context, which requires a preceeding plural subject. Therefore it is safer to restore the perlative of the chapter name according to the pattern found in the next stanza (see a 1). Accordingly, one of the first words of the sentence ought to be yoko 'thirst', which is the regular match of Skt. tṛṣṇā-.

I have written the (Puṣpa)varga: As it is the pleasure of bees to smell flowers, may the wish [and] the inclination towards all virtues be more powerfull than that! May

Den (Puṣpa)varga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: Wie [es] das Verlangen der Bienen [ist], Blumen zu riechen, [so] möchte[n] mir stärker als das Wunsch [und] Neigung zu allen Tugenden entstehen.

The (Puṣpa)varga I have written [wishing]: As [it is] the desire of the bees to smell flowers, [just so] may, more strongly than that, the wish [for and] the inclination [towards] all virtues arise in me!

all the beings become decorated with the (pure smell of the good conduct [= śīla]) through this deed! May I understand the body [as being] fragile, somewhat like a pot, and may (I) not cling [to it]! 25. Through
(the writing) of the Aśvavarga may I tame the fierce horses of the sense functions! May (I) myself always in (all births) be provided with the force of patience!
Durch das (Schreib)en des Aśvavarga möchte ich die wilden Āyatana-Pferde bändigen.
By (writ)ing the Aśvavarga, may I subdue the wild Āyatana-horses.
May I obtain the chariot driver of the wisdom, the excellent one, may he tame me accurately, [being] resolute in the Law, harnessed far away from the sensual spheres ... 26.

Den (Krodhavava)rga habe ich geschrieben. Durch die Frucht dieser Tat möge mir dieser Wunsch zustande kommen: Solange ich mich auch im Saṃsāra befinden sollte, möchte nicht die Trübung Zorn mich betreffend(?) gesehen werden; [und] (wenn auch) selbst Gemeine mir die (harten) Schwerter (der Worte) regnen lassen sollten, [so] möge mir das Herz [als] der Brustschmuck der Geduld fest sein, ehrerbietig gegen jeder[mann].

The (Krodhava)rga I have written. Through the fruit of this deed, may this wish be granted for me: as long as ever I may find myself in the saṃsāra, may the defilement of wrath not be seen in my case(?); [and] (even when) even miserly ones should let rain the (hard) swords (of speech) [over] me, may my heart, [as] the pectoral of patience, be steadfast, respectful towards every[body].
I have written the Krodhavarga. As the fruit of this deed, may this wish be fulfilled: As long as I would turn in the Saṃsāra, may the anger [and] the passion not see me as [being] enraged. (Even if)
(Den Krodhava)rga habe ich geschrieben: Durch die Frucht d[ies]er Tat möge mir dieser Wunsch in Erfüllung gehen: ...
(The Krodhava)rga I have written. As the fruit of [this] deed, this wish may be fulfilled for me: ...

they let rain really [as mean] as villains the swords of (harsh words), may my heart remain firm, [being] this pectoral ornament of patience, [and] respectful to everybody. 27. (I have written the) Tathāgatav(arga:) May I come together
(with wise ones) through this deed! When these ones will beat the drum of the Law, roaring the four truths, may (I) obtain (to hear) from the mouth of the omniscients in person
the (eight)fold noble path! May this wheel of the Law which has been turned by the king of rṣis remain for long! 28. (I have) written the Śrutavarga, (the excellent one)

(in order to hear) the Law consisting of eighty thousand parts. May I seize [it] at the first lecture [lit. hearing] [and] may I teach [it] to others without flaw (?) while going into mission. May I understand clearly
the internal (senses) [and] the (external obj)ects, may I take the thing belonging to my own as [meaningless as] mere sound [and] may I not cling [to it]. 29. I have written the Ātmavarga: (May I)
Möchte ich meine eigenen Dinge nur als Wort erfassen [und] nicht [daran] haften!
May I take my own things only as a word [and] not cling [to them]!
(be able to ta)me (myself) in all (bi)rths, always desirous of the speaking of these ones, having evoked the inclination to be close to the good ones! (In) sharing ...
Nach dem Wort [wtl. Sagen] derer stets verlangend, möcht ich die Neigung, bei Guten [wtl. zu den Guten hin] zu sein, hervorrufen.
Always yearning for the speech of these, may I evoke the inclination to be with good ones [lit. towards the good].

comments.comment: An almost complete leaf.

The parallel fragments a 1 and b 3 both have the expected form ynauṣkak instead of ynauṣak. In general, this mansucript has more recent spellings and bears traces of late and erouneous forms, while the other two are written in standard orthography. Note further that b 3 has an allative kärtsauñeś.
krentaunaṃś is not a correct form, which would be krentaunaś(c); it seems that the scribe has extended the mark of oblique plural to the plurale tantum.

The reading toko is warranted, but it must be due to a writing error for tākoṃ; the scribe apparently has copied the vowel ‹o› of the neighboring akṣaras and in addition forgot the anusvāra (as he did in the following line). This is another confirmation for copying from mansucripts instead of oral dictation.
karsoym (a3) and källoym (a5) have double virāma writing of the akālk-type.
As for the last colon, the reading is uncertain, we may have ṣ/pal(·)e (·)it/ke; since the metaphor is unclear (and may come from hippology), any restoration would be speculative.

emañña seems to be an adverb, according to the second attestation in b 6; accordingly, ñiś ought to be the direct object of lkoyentär. Judging from the context it should refer to the state of rage or folly resulting from passions, esp. anger.
The parallel b 4 has the reading newent ce, which is more correct.
The grammatically incorrect restoration eneṅkāññ(eṃ) is warranted by the parallel a2. It is most likely due to a copyist error. See the commentary there.
The parallel text a 3 has a slightly different wording; in this version the demonstrative ceṃts refers to the good ones (= krentäṃ) which are mentioned in the next colon.

Here we have rmamñe eru – the parallel text a 3-a4 confirms this – instead of rmamñ= erīmar with regular sandhi in the parallel text b1. As a matter of fact, rmamñ= erīmar is more consistent with the repetitive use of optative forms in this text and it shows regular sandhi. Since the sequence with hiatus is odd for a metrical passage, one would assume that rmamñ= erīmar is more original.

line.tr: Den Peyālavarga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: Die Aussprüche, die mit Gesetzlosigkeit verbunden [sind], möchte ich nicht preisen, möchte ich nicht sagen. Für das Buddhawort [und] die Śāstras möchte ich Eifer zeigen. Fest im Gesetz stehend, möchte ich gern, [und sei es auch nur] einen [einzigen] Tag, leben: Dies Leben [wäre] das beste. Nicht aber möchte ich ich ein hundert Jahre [währendes] Leben, [das] mit Gesetzlosigkeit verbunden [ist], preisen.

The Peyālavarga I have written. The utterances that [are] connected to lawlessness I do not want to praise, do not want to say. [It is] for the word of the Buddha and the śāstras [that] I will show zeal. Standing steadfast in the law I would like to live [and be it only for] one [single] day: this life [would be] the best. But I do not want to praise a life [lasting for] a hundred years [that is] connected to lawlessness.

Den Mitravarga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: In allen Geburten möchte ich gute Freunde erlangen. Mit den Weisen, [die] sich für eine gute Sache entschieden [haben], möge mir Zusammenkommen sein. Mit Gemeinen möchte ich nicht Freundschaft schließen/Nicht möchte ich die Gemeinen lieben, um [nicht] alle Tugenden zu verlieren [wtl. zum Verlorengehen aller Tugenden]. Die richtig Überlegenden, die auf sittliche Haltung Drängenden möchten meine Freunde sein.

The Mitravarga I have written [wishing]: In all births, may I make good friends. With the wise ones, [that have] decided on a good thing, may I meet with them. May I not make friends with mean ones/May I not love the mean ones, to the loss of all virtues. The properly considerate ones, the ones insisting on the moral conduct, may [these] be my friends.
Und nicht möge den Fünfgeburten[wesen] das Auge des Verstandes vom Star der Verkehrtheit [des Irrtums] bedeckt werden.
And may not the eye of sense be covered with the cataract of error for the [beings of the] five incarnations.

Weil ich den Pāpavarga geschrieben habe, möchte ich alles Böse in allen Geburten vertreiben. Zum Zustandekommen aller (Tugenden) möchte ich fähig sein, [mein] Denken zu allen Zeiten zu bändigen. Was der Befehl des Allerkenners [ist], eben daran möchte ich mit Körper, Wort [und] Denken halten, an (verdienstvollen Werk)en unersättlich [und] stets bemüht, di e drei Wurzeln zu vernichten.

Because I have written the Pāpavarga, may I expel all evil in all births. May I be capable of the development of all (virtues), to restrain [my] thinking at all times. What[ever] the command of the Omniscient, to precisely this I want to adhere with body, speech [and] thought, insatiable for (meritorious deed)s [and] always striving to destroy the three roots.

comments.comment: There are many forms with o-mobile or preserved word-final -ä; on the other hand, we have some late spellings like the genitive plural in -ets.
A complete leaf but without the leaf number preserved. It is immediately followed by .
yūkoym has a double virāma writing of the akālk-type. As often, the varga names such as peyālavārgä are written without virāma, but the -ä does not count metrically.
källoym has a double virāma writing of the akālk-type, but metrically one has to restore the final -ä. The final -ä of the varga name mitravārgä also counts metrically in this case.

The text clearly has rittowo, which is an also otherwise attested o-mobile form of the nom.sg. PPt rittau. However, in order to construct it with śaul, we would expect an oblique form rittoṣo, which is actually confirmed by rittoṣ in the parallel text b 4. So we may either assume a mere misspelling, or we have to reckon with a variant formulation and the colon being a hypothetical clause of its own. Note that we do have other variant wordings in other passages of Udānastotra parallels.
Note the spelling aiśaumyeṃpa for aiśaumyeṃmpa.
akālk is written without virāma, but the final -ä does not count metrically.
Note that mällarṣkaṃ has a late ending of the nominative plural masculine (for -añ), which is surprising in view of the other correct nom.pl. endings in the same line.

śtwer empreṃ is unexpected for the notion of the "four truths", which is usually śtwāra emprenma. But even with sandhi śtwār=emprenma it would not fit the meter. It would be very speculative to assume that emprenma has been truncated to empren metri causa and that then a copiyst has wrongly resolved the sandhi and replaced the form with the masculine śtwer. No solution is provided by , to whom Thomas refers. It is easier to assume that the author replaced the non-metrical śtwār=emprenma by a dvigu compound being a calque of Skt. catur-ārya-satya- of the type tri-ratna- = TA tri-ñemi. Moreover the prose expression would be śtwāra emprenmaṣṣi ṣarnesa or śtwāra emprenmaṣṣana ṣarnesa.

āstr= eśne stands for āstry= eśne, which is actually attested in a 5. It may be a simple misspelling or even an allegro form. Furthermore, we have here plural instead of dual agreement with the adjective aiśamñeṣṣe.
Note the word play between the grundverb infinitive yātatsi and the causative infinitive yātässi.
The three roots correspond to the three akuśala-mūla, namely greed, anger, and delusion.

The restoration (bhav)ākarñai has been proposed and discussed by . It refers to the notion of Skt. bhavāgra- 'peak of the universe, limit of existence', see . The form is obviously an oblique singular of a feminine abstract and it cannot be connected with the masculine plural kauṃ-ñäkteṃts. It is unwarranted to imagine that it is miswritten for bhavākarñeṃ [pace Thomas], because the Sanskrit term is never used in this way. On the other hand, there is a Sanskrit phrase yāvad bhavāgram "to the limit of existence", which most probably has been imitated here with the Tocharian temporal accusative.

line.tr: ... In (all bi)rth circles may the pure spirit never disappear for me! 36. (Through the) wri(ting of the Sukhavarga) ...
Möge mir in allen Geburtenreihen das reine Denken niemals vergehen!
May clear thinking never leave me in all sequences of births!
May I vanquish the untamed [and] shameless spirit, may I subjugate all the passions! ... the hurting ...
through (body, spe)ech [and] spirit may I always evolve according to the Law that has been taught by the good ones! (37.) ...
... May all the beings of the five births be able to tame [their] spirit (in) all (the births)! ...
... May I myself recognize the five elements [= the five skandhas] that ought to be known! And may I not cling [to them]! (38.) ... (For sure my wish may be fulfilled!)
Die fünf zu wissenden Skandhas möchte ich [als] höchstes Ziel erkennen [und] nicht [daran] haften!
The five skandhas to know I want to recognize [as] the highest aim [and] not cling [to them]!
May I have a pure way of living [lit. living of life] consisting of wisdom by this three-fold deed! (Avoiding) su(ffering and happiness in the sharing ... (May I avoid the danger of the)
(pass)ions, [and] may I always become without anger through this deed! 39. (Which [= the Brāhmaṇavarga] makes rain jewels of meanings like) the cintāmaṇi (gem),

Den wie das Cintāmaṇi-Juwel Besitzesperlen regnen lassenden vorzüglichen [und] (aller)ausgezeichnetsten Brāhmaṇavarga habe ich mit [diesem] guten Wunsch geschrieben: Den achtgliedrigen edlen Pfad, der zur Nirvāṇa-Stadt führt, möchte ich offenbar machen! Das Glück des Erlöschens aller Leiden möchten die Fünfgeburtenwesen erlangen durch meinen eigenen Wunsch.

The excellent [and] (most) splendid Brāhmaṇavarga, which, like the Cintāmaṇi jewel lets rain possession-pearls, I have written with [this] good wish: may I make evident the eight-part noble path that leads to the city of nirvāṇa! May the beings of the five incarnations attain the bliss of extinction of all suffering through my own wish.
I have written the (excellent) Brāhmaṇavarga, (super)ior (to everything, may I make manifest) the noble eightfold path (that goes to the city of Nirvāṇa!)
May [the beings] (of the five births) reach the happiness (consisting in the extinction of all sufferings) through the wish coming from me! 40. (Some) say also that: ...
through love [and] belief in the omniscient. How many ak(ṣaras there are) in the book ...
... through the Law [and] faithfullness. 41. In the regnal year of the growing k(ing) of the kings ...
... by a great wish, through the fruit of this deed (may) the be(ings) of the five births ...

comments.comment: There are some late spellings such as krentats (a3) and yāmortse (b6) and some writing errors in b1.
After stanza 40 there follows a conclusion including a colophon which is different from the one found in the parallel manuscript , which is itself completed by .
This fragment immediately follows . Left piece of a leaf with the string hole preserved.
The text has pek (with fremdzeichen pa!) tākoyt, which is due to a copyist error.

line.tr: Having run again and again through the cycle of countless rebirths, [9b] you [were] longing for a house builder; rebirth again and again [means] suffering. The first strophe. [= Uv 31.6]
O maker of houses, you have been seen: you will not make a house again. All your rafters are broken and the top of the house is destroyed. [10a]
In your mind having come to destruction, here you have certainly reached disappearance. This is the end of the second

strophe. [10c] [= Uv 31.7] These two stanzas have been told; thereupon precisely [follows] the commentary: first [it is said:] [Someone] came in the surroundings of the Jetavana-grove [and] the Buddha lord

saw him [= Vajraka, i.e. one adorned with a jewel] from afar on the earth. [11a] Vajraka spoke to him [= Buddha] from afar. This one [= Buddha] indeed told him: “I have seen you from afar.” [11b] Dharmaruci
said to him [= Buddha]: “O Omniscient, a very long time ago, [11c] he [= Vajraka] went down to the earth and honored the tender feet of the omniscient.” [11d]
In a remote time, they say, Dharmaruci and the Buddha lord [12a] were brothers. Then they (made vows and the first brother said): [12b]
“In innumerable kalpas I will thereupon indeed strive for the ṛṣi-hood, [12c] I will accumulate virtues in gre(at number having faith)

[In a former life, the Buddha said,] «in asaṃkhyeya kalpas I will then strive for the ṛṣi-hood: I will accumulate virtues, [and] (I will) not (enter) the nirvāṇa (before).» The second, [Dharmaruci in a former life,] said, «through such a long time I cannot bear, through sorrows … I will become an arhat.» (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)
in the nirvāṇa.” [12d] The second [brother] said: “Through such long times I will not suffer. [13a] In order to be freed from those sufferings [and] from the saṃ(sāra),
I will become an Arhat.” [13b] The one who chose the status of omniscient, he has become Śākyamuni now. [13c] (The one who) chose the status of Arhat,
he has become Dharmaruci by name. [13d] In innumerable kalpas, they say, in three time periods, [14a]
Dharmaruci made encounter with the Omniscient [= Buddha] [who still was] in the Bodhisattva state. [14b] And now in the second birth indeed he [= Vajraka] has been
born among the sea monsters; [14c] numerous kalpas of destruction and evolution had been crossed by him. [14d] Therefore, the Omniscient [= Buddha] told him
the stanzas from wide afar. [15a] Having been heard, the glory of the stanzas spread high for a cause indeed. [15b] Dharmaruci ... [15c]

comments.comment: The metre is 4 x 7+8 (in principle 4+3 + 3+5). In general, the Tocharian translation does not preserve the segmentation of the Sanskrit pāda structure, because it is metrical itself. Final ś in this manuscript is consistently written with non-fremdzeichen 〈śa〉 and virāma, which is not uncommon in classical texts.

This series of fragments PK AS 6 consists of the 12 pieces, in theory PK AS 6A-L. But for some unknown reason fragment PK AS 6G was reclassified as PK NS 22, and the fragment PK AS 6F was joined with PK AS 6E. All these pieces belong to the same seven-line manuscript except PK AS 6J, which has only 5 lines, a different size and ductus and does not contain Udānālaṅkāra proper.

The nominal phrase ost yāmṣeñcai (= Skt. gṛha-kāraka-) has to be understood as the direct object of the participle ñäskemane from the beginning of the next pāda. It has a metaphorical meaning of the mind influenced by desire. The translation of the Sanskrit stanza Udv. 31.61 ends with näno näno ‘again and again’ translating Skt. punaḥ punaḥ. The following words belong to the commentary.
The PPt nom.sg.masc. käskowä for standard käskau shows the preservation of final -ä usually written as -o in classical texts; however, other classical texts also show preservation (cf. ).

One can restore sp(ārtta)[lyñ](e), the verbal noun of spārtt(ā)- ‘to turn; behave’. It is recorded already with the meaning ‘behavior, evolution’. Here sp(ārtta)[lyñ](e) is the calque of Skt. vṛtti-, abstract of the synonymous verb vṛt- ‘to roll, turn, behave’ in the specialized sense ‘commentary, gloss, explanation (of a sūtra)’.
The form jetaṃvaṃ in effect stands for the expected jetavaṃ (cf. jetavanne in the same manuscript PK AS 6D a 4, b 1 and passim in other Udānālaṅkāra texts), a borrowing of Skt. jetavana-.

We clearly have a derivative of TB waśīr, which is a borrowing of Skt. vajra- ‘diamond’. The adjective TB waśiräṣṣe (similarly TA waśirṣi) is recorded so far with the meaning ‘pertaining to a diamond, made of diamonds’. But here we have to assume that waśirṣe is the rendering of a proper name, Buddhist Sanskrit vajraka-, the name of a spirit (yakṣa) that has been converted by the Buddha (cf. , 467a); note that also Sanskrit vajraka- is used as an adjective meaning ‘adamantine, hard like a diamond’.

The adjective anāṣkarai is the oblique singular fem. of anāṣkare* which is based on the adverb TB aṣkār ‘back’. This expression certainly refers to a remote past, so that the prefix an- ‹ *ān- ‹ *æn- has intensive function here. The form omp(r)o[t](r)iṃ ought to be interpreted as omprotriñ, nominative plural of an adjective in -i with the function of appurtenance, cf. with different suffixes the TB nom.pl. compound forms omprotärcci ‘co-brothers’ and TB nom.pl. eṣerñana ‘co-sisters’ based on the oblique stems protär and ṣer, respectively.

After the beginning of the narrative we have to assume at the end of this line a short sentence introducing the following direct speech. Since in line b2 the direct speech of the second brother is precisely introduced by wate weña, here we have to assume a similar reference to the first brother and speaker (= the future Buddha Śākyamuni). One may very tentatively restore cai (añmaññante ṣe) ‘they made wishes; the first one [wished]’.

The best restoration seems to be a derivative of the root späntā- ‘to trust, to be faithful’, which usually constructed with the locative, and the phrase “having trust in the Nirvana” is already recorded (B 241 a 5).

The form poyśñi as such makes no sense. In addition, we would expect the abstract poyśiññe parallel to arhanteññe arttāte in the next pāda here. The only sensible possibility is to assume a wrong copying of the metrically correct text poyśiññ=arttāte with sandhi involving inversion in the graphemes.

The form saṃwartwiwart qualifying the kalpas is formed by the combination of two loan words from Sanskrit terms: saṃvarta- ‘destruction (of the world)’ and vivarta- ‘evolution (of the world)’ (cf. , 499b and 540a).

The plural form ślaukanma is hypercorrect for ślokanma; cf. the gen.sg. ślaukantse in B 95 a 6. Therefore it remains uncertain if the genitive plural, which may be restored later in the same line, had o or au.
The leaf number is 34 or 35.

comments.comment: The metre is 4 x 7+8 (in principle 4+3 + 3+5).
follows immediately.

The standard form of the comitative sg. of śīl, a loan word from Skt. śīla- is actually śīlmpa; one may assume either simplification of the cluster, or ligatura, or the usage of the older form -pa of the comitative affix. If one restores a secondary adjective war(a)ṣlyñ(eṣṣe) one gets a relatively common expression combining an adjective in -ṣṣe (TA -ṣi) with a metaphorical term, in our case ‘hero’ (of the type pelaikneṣṣe naumiye ‘the jewel of the Law’ = “the Law [which is] a jewel”). According to parallels, TB waraṣlyñe (TA wrāṣlune) translates Skt. bhāvanā- ‘contemplation, reflection, development of the mind’.

For the end of the form (e)tre[ntä] Lévi had the reading trewä, but this does not lead anywhere. The alternative reading gives a verse form of an oblique singular masc. of an adjective etreu* ‘provided with a hero’ presupposed by etreuññe ‘heroic’ (B 274 b 2).

After eṣe the akṣara 〈sa〉 has been erased. Therefore the original writing was most probably °mpa ṣesa with the reinforcement of the comitative by an adverb, which is actually found in line a 1. But then the scribe realized that this sequence had one syllable too much for the metre and he corrected it by modifying ṣe to eṣe (the alternative adverb with the same meaning), which implied sandhi with the preceding vowel.

The forms ostä and aipoṣä in pāda 80a show preservation of the final -ä due to the metre, even though they are colon-internal; in b3 we have colon-final pontaṃtsä, which is the more regular place for this kind of preservation. In the first case it is certainly an archaism preserved in a direct quote from the Udānavarga.
The akṣara 〈ka〉 has been added below the line in a smaller writing, apparently by the same hand that added the double dot at the end of pāda 80b and also the leaf number on the margin.
TB amāno, a loan word from Iranian *āmāna-, shows o-mobile like many other loan words from Indian or Iranian.

The reading maute is certain and confirmed by a second occurrence in the following leaf (PK AS 6C a3), because the scribe distinguishes carefully between 〈n〉 and 〈ta〉. However, there is also a form mauṃ in 20 b 3, archaic meu(-) in broken context in 145 a8, which is supposed to mean ‘avarice’ (; ). Pace Adams, our maute should not be read as maune and hence taken as the nom.sg. beside the obl.sg. mauṃ, all the less so since such an inflection is without parallels.

Apparently, one would expect the oblique plural of the noun twere ‘door’, since the senses are conceived as (many) openings, and the preceding adjective is an oblique plural masc. as well. Therefore, one may surmise the omission of an anusvāra.

The phrase TB nauṣ pāke postäṃ pāke iṣintse seems to render the Sanskrit adverb pūrvarātrāpararātram ‘during the first and the second half of the night’ (: s.v.). Note that the oblique here is used in temporal function.
The ligatura 〈ṣpa〉 in nauṣ pāke was written carelessly.

The form etsarkle has to be taken as a direct object of the preceding verb; pace it is not an adverb but the substantivized adjective, being the calque of Skt. ātāpana- ‘self-castigation’ () based on tsärk(ā)- ‘to burn, torment’.

It does not seem possible to construct l(k)ātsi as an infinitive depending on the verb cämp- ‘to be able’. Since the meter often causes deviation from normal word order, one may restore an adjective l(k)ātsi(ṣṣe) as epithet of the preceding noun palsko. It presupposes that lkātsi has been substantivized in order to provide a calque of Skt. darśana- ‘vision’, which designates a progressive stage in the religious development, cf. . The sentence as restored states clearly the opposite behavior to the previous status of Nanda as described in line a7.

does not seriously destroy a house that is well-covered, [83a] in the same manner passion does not seriously destroy a mind well-exercised.” [83b] [= Uv 31.17]

comments.comment: The metre is 4 x 7+8 (in principle 4+3 + 3+5).
precedes immediately.
Colon-final pontantsä shows preservation of final -ä, which is the regular place for this kind of preservation and also found in the preceding leaf PK AS 6B b3.

The phrase aknātsaṃñ=emāno shows vowel sandhi over the colon boundary, which is caused by the addition of a supplementary syllable mā in the colon in contrast to the similar sequence in PK AS 6B b3-4. In addition, the redactor has opted for the contraction product e instead of a. A similar discrepancy between meter and sandhi we find in b2: krentaunamp= ; ākalye, and consonant sandhi in b7: os= ; tärkau. For the reading maute, see PK AS 6B b4.

The word order is wrong; it should read toṃ śtwāra kälyminmeṃ instead. The nom.pl. feminine PPt pälkowwa for standard pälkauwa shows a variant usually found in the nom.sg. masculine -ow (with variant spellings), which represents the older form beside standard -au. Note that in PK AS 6A b6 we find the standard form kätkauwa.

At the beginning of this line one may restore swese ‘rain’, which would make good sense as subject of the sentence; however, since it is already found as subject of the preceding clause, this repetition seems unlikely. One may also consider a demonstrative pronoun followed by a particle like su tsa, or rather a demonstrative determining following ostne. But the best restoration would be the comparative conjunction mäkte that would reinforce the parallelism with the apodosis that starts at the beginning of the next pāda.

In pāda 85d the relative pronoun mäkcew is referred to by the suffix pronoun -neś. The singular indrīsa is unexpected because the senses are always plural, also in this text (cf. PK AS 6B b5). The singular is probably caused by the meter, which requires only three syllables at the end of the first colon.

The compound snai-mäktauñe ought to be interpreted as an adverb, while eṅkaltse is the nominative singular of a derivative of eṅkäl ‘passion’. It corresponds to Skt. aparāyaṇa- ‘without ultimate goal, without refuge’.

The oblique plural of wiṣai, a loan word from Skt. viṣaya- ‘domain, sphere of the senses’, can only be understood as an accusative of extension depending on the verb käsk(ā)- ‘to scatter’. Accordingly, the PPt käskau describes the state of mind of the person subjected to the senses, which is attracted by all sorts of external objects.

comments.comment: The segmentation of the syllables before the end of the pāda remains uncertain. Based on the reading by Lévi, lañc has been interpreted as a verbal form followed by uwe ‘learned, smart’. Accordingly, lañc is registered by the handbooks as a subjunctive form of lä-n-t- with a 2. singular suffix pronoun lañ-c. But the connection with the following context, which contains a 2. plural imperative, is irrational. Therefore, one may conceive that the pāda ends with something like (śau)l añcuwe or (came)l añcuwe with añcuwe being an adjective matching the TA adverb āñc ‘below, inferior, down’. Be that as it may, it is relatively certain that this story illustrates the commentary of the stanza Uv 31.26, which is about the control of anger. Since in this story there is apparently a famine, no doubt caused by a drought, it can be attributed to the anger of nāgas (i.e., water spirits), who decided to abandon the country of Magadha. Most probably the Bodhisattva pacified them by telling this precise stanza causing them to come back.
Due to metrical considerations, in the syntagma māgatṣeṃ ypaunane the adjective is masculine instead of feminine.

At the end of the pāda 103a the colon aiśi yāmtsi mäkte nauṣ has seven syllables instead of the usual six. This does not mean, however, that this line is incorrect because the preceding colon could have six syllables.

At the beginning of the line kare is certainly the end of a 3.pl. active preterite verb form followed by a demonstrative. Very tentatively one may restore a complete colon (lakle yai)kare ceu “they drove away this suffering”.

One can see erased text below the present one from the beginning down to spe. The number 103 is still readable right in front of the schnurloch. Because of that one may assume that the scribe has corrected a previous incorrect line (either miscopied or a false redaction with respect to the meter).

In the commentary to the Udānavarga quoted by , note 1 it is mentioned that the following stanza was told by the Buddha in order to convert the brahmin Pipralīkasāra. Later in line b2 he is referred to by the epithet Skt. vipratyanīka-, a reinforced variant of Skt. pratyanīka- ‘hostile, opposed, withstanding’. This epithet has been chosen because the Udānavarga stanza in question contains the form Skt. pratyanīkasāra- referring to a person resisting to the teaching of the Law. The story is based on the capacity of the Buddha to read minds and to know in advance the intention of his questioners.

In the second syllable of mäsketrä the vowel was originally written as ‹ī› as in the previous occurrence in a 4 and later corrected. The suggested restoration of the infinitive parktsi leaves us with one missing syllable. In any case, one may imagine that the original text had something like: “I will go in the presence of the Buddha and I will try to ask him questions in mind only.”

The allative pūdñäkteśca shows preservation of the final vowel -ä, which is here written as -a as sometimes happens in the case of graphemes without fremdzeichen; such preservation in front of a colon boundary is not uncommon even in classical texts. All other allative forms in this text are written as -ś showing simplification of the cluster common to classical texts. In addition, this -ś in virāma position is written with non-fremdzeichen, which is actually also quite common for any final -ś in virāma position in standard texts.

The Skt. compound pratyanīkasāra- ‘being hostile on principle’ has been literally translated by klaṅkälyñe-prakre ‘having doubt as fundament’; note that the second member is not the abstract prakrauñe ‘essence, substance’, which is used elsewhere to match Skt. sāra-, because of metrical requirements.
Skt. subhāṣitam (Uv 31.27b) is translated elsewhere by TB kartse weweñu, see, e.g., B 20 b 1 (= Uv 8.11a), but here it would not fit the meter. Therefore, kartse ākṣu seems possible.

The translator has used the conjunction wat twice in contrast to a single occurrence of Skt. vā in Uv 31.27d. Apart from metrical considerations, this repetition is probably used in order to ascertain the cohesion of the nominal clause.

comments.comment: The old manuscript PK AS 6F has been joined with this fragment.

An alternative reading would be sārmäśke. However, both sārmäśke and sārme (if written correctly) are otherwise unknown. Both such forms may either belong to sārm ‘seed’, or be from a different word altogether. In the former case one has to assume a misspelled loc.sg. sārm(n)e or a misspelled nom./obl. sg. sārmä (or sārmo?). But one has to admit that a reference (either concrete or metaphorical) to ‘seed’ does not lead to a clearer understanding of this quite difficult passage. There are additional difficulties: first the accent of sārmäśke is unexpected for a diminutive of a base word sārm (unless it is based on a loan word, though there is no Sanskrit word suggesting itself as basis); hence, the separation sārmäś kewi is preferable, since kewi is the expected nom.pl. of keu (cf. TA nom.pl. kowi). Therefore, nom.sg. sārme and the obl. stem sārm belong to the same paradigm of a noun that may also refer to an animal, probably either a ‘calf’ or ‘bull’, which can both actually be derived from sārm ‘seed’.
This difficult passage should belong to a set story illustrating the following maxim that warns against the dangers of imagination.
Since a genitive singular in -entse can only belong to a substantive, waipeccentse is the only possible restoration.
At the beginning of this line we certainly have a 3.sg. middle verbal form with suffixed pronoun.
The form weṣñi is the nominative dual of an adjective weṣaññe based on weṣ ‘appearance, guise’, itself a loan word from Skt. veṣa-.

The text announces two Udānavarga stanzas that ought to be 31.33-34. The content of the first one is summarized and commented upon in pādas 14c-d, but we do not have a literal translation as we do elsewhere. The adjectives Skt. sthūla- ‘rough’ and sūkṣma- ‘fine’ have been transposed by abstracts of the corresponding TB adjectives; one may restore aśāwñe (from aśāwäññe) derived from aśāwe 'rough' parallel to lykaśkäññe from lykaśke 'fine'. The translation insists on the resistance against the destructive effects of imagination.
Twice attested tsäṅkā-ñ clearly has a suffixed 1. singular pronoun, and even though the Buddha is speaking, such a reference is somewhat disturbing.
One has to assume that pāda 15a represents the negative counterpart of the preceding sentence with protasis and apodosis.

comments.comment: Recto and verso cannot be determined. There may be a meter with a cola of seven syllables in b1 ff.
Middle part of a leaf.
Here we have a quotation of Uv 30.11cd without direct translation. It is possible that the two preceding pādas were also quoted before.

The Sanskrit is corrupt. One may venture to recognize jala-bhujaga- ‘watersnake’. This word is recorded as variant of Skt. uraga- ‘snake’ in a pāda repeated often in the Udānavarga (18.21d; 32.55-80).
This may be part of a colophon composed in Sanskrit referring to a Kuchean king bearing the Sanskrit name Āryapūṣpa.

If read correctly, śälmoñ would be a nominative plural form of a masculine noun because of śwālyi. In that case this form seems to have mixed the inflection of the stems of class VI.2 (type pyapyo, pyapyaiñ), which show accent shift, with the inflection of the adjective and agent nouns in -mo, which have a nom.pl. in -oñ. It cannot be an agent noun of the type aiśamo, verse form aiśmo, since in this case one would expect †ślamo, †śalmo.
tallā= wnolme stands for tallāw wnolme with sandhi (for tallāu onolme).

In both instances one can recognize a well-known Sanskrit compound pratyeka-buddha- lit. ‘Buddha for himself alone’ (cf. ), a term which is frequent in Mahāyāna texts. This term has been transposed by simply replacing Skt. buddha- by its TB match, while using a hypercorrect form pratyaika with ‹ai› instead of ‹e›.

comments.comment: There are several forms with o-mobile immediately in front of a colon/pāda end, i.e., in the normal position in verse.

The meter seems to be 4 x 14 (7/7), but in a5 we have an eight-syllable colon. In a2 and a4 two cross signs slightly above the line can be seen; usually, this sign marks a correction, but here nothing was added or deleted. The crosses may, however, signal the omission of a whole pāda or stanza, since the written stanza numbers are difficult to reconcile with the lacunas, i.e. it seems that text is indeed missing.

The actual piece consists of two joint fragments, only the left part of which has been edited by Lévi and commented upon by Sieg. Only due to this joint giving clear stanza numbers it has been possible to distinguish between recto and verso side. Hence, the actual sides are in the reverse order in contrast to the first edition.

The text contains the otherwise unknown ṣlātäṃ, but since there is a corrections cross after this form (though without visible correction), it is quite reasonable to assume a correction to plātäṃ ‘talks, speeches’. The form matre must be the first member of a compound, as in matre-wse ‘having a sharp poison’.
There are two variants of the 2.pl. active transitive Imperative of wik(ā)-, pwikso (a2) and pwīkaso (a5), no doubt due to metrical requirements.

The reading °īyaṃne by Lévi is certain; hence the assumption by to read °īyeṃne and to simply restore (kerc)īyeṃne is wrong. Actually, the restoration (w)[er](ts)īyaṃne makes much more sense with respect to the context. The segmentation of the akṣarsas before the verb parskäskeṃ is uncertain. We may deal with the adverb yaka; lokek could in theory be a form of lauke plus emphatic -k. However, the connection of these two adverbs with ‘frighten’ is not clear semantically. Therefore, one may venture the guess that lokekyaka is based on an incorrect sanskritization of a Middle Indic form of Sanskrit lohitaka- ‘some sort of insect’ () or of Skt. lohitākṣa- ‘with red eyes’ (the name of a snake) (M-W, 909b). Accordingly, lokekyaka would be the plural of a noun lokekyak*. As for ykeṃ, the only sensible interpretation is to regard it as a form of an adverb yṅkeṃ ‘on the earth’ comparable to iṅkauṃ ‘by day’; note that the nasal in these formations may be missing (cf. yñakteṃ, yśāmna). It is unclear what the cross means, since there is no written correction.

If -sa is the perlative affix (which is the only sensible semantic solution), it is wrongly placed after the adjective (instead of the substantive wassi). In addition, this clause has one syllable to many. One may surmise that the original, metrically correct text had the verse form śilṣesa. The copyist transposed it into the usual prose form.

The reading of the number 28 as per Lévi is certain (pace ). One has to admit, however, that the restitution of the meter from the number of syllables (taking the pāda digits for granted) is difficult.
The 2. plural middle kalträ is the first attestation of the expected zero-grade stem of the Sub I stem of käl- ‘to suffer, endure’ (1.sg. kelu).
Due to context narahānte is a genitive singular of a proper name Narahānt, which is obviously borrowed from Sanskrit, possibly a false rendering of narānta-.

line.tr: But who are called the gods with form there? If one takes part with them, … the cause therein. (cf 5)
Welche jedoch die gestalthaften (Götter genannt) werden ...
[Those] who, however, are (called the gods) that have shape, ...
Who has done deeds and accumulated them, ten all pure and not having made dirty, by these deeds [he] has a birth among the gods with form; so is the saying of the omniscient [Buddha]. (cf 5)
Darüber hinaus jedoch werden die Götter gestaltlos genannt.
Beyond that, however, the gods are called amorphic.
Seven laws there determine [lit. lead] the birth; there are seven great and excellent meditations—if he has practised that, he is born among these gods (scil. without form). (cf 6)
I will further tell the ways of the deeds, listen to it; the good, the bad, and the mixed too. Having heard this, you will get skills in doing deeds and not err in many ways. (cf 6–7)
Es gibt eine Tat, [die] zum Bestimmt-Geboren-werden führt [wtl. sich wendet].
There is a deed which leads [lit. turns itself] to certainly being born.
What I said like that, that I will say in detail. (cf 7)
But what deed is it, if one does it in another place, from which one obtains the ripening in another place? (cf 9)
If he aspires to [re]births [and] does good deeds, he is through this deed not certainly [re]born. (cf 9)

Er macht sich zu Geburten reif, wenn er gute Taten tut, aber durch solche [gute] Tat [allein] wird er nicht bestimmt geboren. Welches aber [ist] die Tat, davon er, [wenn] er [sie] an einem Ort tut, an einem anderen Ort die Reife [Vergeltung] erlangt? [wtl. Welches aber [ist] die Tat: Tut er [sie] an dem einen Ort, [dann] erlangt er das Reifen davon an einem anderen Ort?] [Antwort:] Das ist die Tat, deren Same [wtl. von welcher Tat der Same], anderswo gesät [wtl. gestreut], an ihm, dem an einen anderen Ort gegangenen, reift.

He makes himself ready for the births, when he does good deeds, but through such [good] deed [alone] he will not be born [into a] specific [place/shape]. But what [is] the deed, from which, [if] he does [it] in one place, he obtains the maturity [requital] in another place? [lit. But what [is] the deed: [if] he does [it] in the one place, [then] he obtains the maturity if it in another place?] [Answer:] That is the deed, the seed of which [lit. of which deed the seed], sown [lit. strewn] elsewhere, matures on him who has gone to another place.

But what is the deed through which the beings here, if they are [re]born in the hells, live [their] whole live[s] there, [and] they do not obtain redemption earlier [and] within that time have their death[s]? (cf 10)

If some beings here do a deed [leading] to be [re]born in hell, and they accumulate it in all ways, and [then] they are not afraid because of this deed, they do not feel disgust, they are not ashamed, [and] they do not repent it, [but] they are glad [and] rejoice, [and] increase their power even more.

[Wenn] hier einige Wesen eine Tat zum In-der-Hölle-Geborenwerden tun und [sie] in jeder Weise anhäufen, [so] fürchten sie sich (infolge) einer solchen Tat nicht [und] empfinden nicht Abscheu, schämen sich nicht, (bereuen) nicht. Sie freuen sich, sind vergnügt [und] mehren deren Kraft noch mehr.

[If] some beings here do a deed to be born in hell and accumulate [it] in every way, they [i.e. the beings] are not afraid (because of) [this] deed, [they] do not feel disgust, [they] are not ashamed, [they] do not (repent). They are happy, merry [and] increase its power even further.

comments.comment: The text shows some preservations of final -ä or its classical form o-mobile; all instances are placed at the usual positions (i.e., colon- and pāda-finally, as well as preceding a clitic). Sometimes we find incorrect vowels such as yāmaṃ-ne (a2), oṃṣäp (a3), ñakteṃne (a4), yänmacer (a5).
Mahākarmavibhaṅga §§ 20-22 () (line a1-a4); Mahākarmavibhaṅga §§ 30-32 (,123), §§ 27-28 () (after line a4)
Until a4 the meter is 4 x 13 (5/8); afterwards 4 x 12 (5/7).
Fragment immediately follows this one.

The colon break falls in to the compound parinirmitavaśa-wartti borrowed from Skt. pari-nirmita-vaśa-vartin-, which refers to the highest class of gods of the realm of desire (; : s.v. paranirmitavaśavartin-).
The privative etrīwaitstse* designates a category of deeds supplementary to good (Skt. kuśala-) and bad (Skt. akuśala-), i.e., Skt. avyākṛta- ‘not distinguished’.

yuwäskeṃ in a 6 and yuwäṣṣäṃ in b 1 were interpreted by as causative of yu- ‘to ripen’ in the meaning “reif machen zu” + allative., since it corresponds to Skt. pariṇāmayati ‘ripen, mature, develop towards, change into’ () in the Sanskrit Mahākarmavibhaṅga 30 (). However, due to morphological reasons, it was analyzed as a form of yu- ‘to seek, inspire, incline towards’ by . This assumption can now be confirmed by the text, because the notion of ripening, maturing is here expressed by derivatives of the root päk- ‘to cook, ripen’. On the other hand, the same phrase with cmela ‘births’ but another root with the meaning ‘to turn towards’ has to be read in b 2 as well; see below.
Pace , Lévi’s reading tänmaṣṣeñca is certain, and there is no need to correct the text in order to get a causative form. tänmaṣṣeñca refers to an agent, lit. ‘reborner’.
One has to read [ai]wästrä ‘turns towards’; the semantically induced reading [yu]wästrä by Lévi and is not warranted.
The scribe forgot the akṣara ‹ke›.
solme is here (and also in PK AS 7C a1) used as an adjective (epithet of śaul) and shows the inflection of the type astare with an oblique singular masc. in -n.

The form maitrajñā is a wrong re-sanskritization of a corrupted form of the proper name maitrayajña- or maitrāyajña-, which is itself an interpretation of a Middle Indic original, cf. , note 10. Pace , one cannot read and restore māträdṛṣṭā(ntne), which was based only on the correction of Lévi's edition without autopsy of the manuscript. One has here a colon of five syllables, the two last ones are clearly tane. It is then impossible to read the loc.pl. of the borrowing of Skt. dṛṣṭānta- "parable, comparison"; the remaining alternative is to restore dṛṣṭā(nt) as nom.sg. agreeing with the preceding demonstrative pronoun.

internalComments.comment: Some beings, if they do a bad deed [11a] and they accumulate it as (much as) it can be accumulated [11b], they are for sure afraid of this deed,
Some beings, if they have done a deed, [13c] [and] if it is accumulated through birth in hell, these will feel fear because of it,
Some being here, if it does evil with the body, [19c] does an evil deed with his word and mind, it is afraid because of this deed,
