line.tr: even if I were obliged (to roll in the Avīci hell) for a long time without limit (lit. without number), (I would rather endure) the damage …
… (the living beings who) are being struck on the head by sufferings separately [for each one]. For that reason, …
(Immediately after having heard that,) King (Kalmāṣapāda obtained) somehow faith in the glory of Buddhahood …
‘For the sake of (whose) life do you abandon your own life?’ Then King Sutasoma …
… after having encouraged [him] (with a glance), says: ‘O you clever one! (You have asked me about) a very difficult matter …

… to make the earth fly (towards the sky) [is] an easy task (lit. pleasure, recreation); [but] among all matters, this [is] an (extreme)ly difficult matter, (to describe the qualities) of the Buddhas …
… of those who step (smoothly), thereupon this earth-goddess will bow close to [their] feet, like someone (female) of reason.
Darauf wird die Erde sich verneigen.
Thereupon the earth will bow.
… (this wonder), because of [his, i.e. the Buddha’s] tender blue eyes it evokes in many instances faith …
… one is never satisfied (looking at him). [His] two curved jaws [are] those of the lion king, holding (as it were) the missile of Hari, …
(The preceding Buddhas of this final?) teacher (were as numerous as grains of sand in the Gaṅgā?). In this manner he fully [is] a receptacle of all virtues.’
(King Kalmāṣapāda) asks: ‘O lord! (If) this splendor of vision (is found on the body) of the Buddha-lord …’
|| In the tune A. || ‘The jewel of thought …

ṣīkaintso: This difficult form is in the edition provisionally interpretated as an agent noun of səyka- 'step'. However, a reading ṣ(p)īkaintso is also possible. This would solve the morphological problems, since this is the regular gen.pl. of ṣpikiye* 'crutch'. If this restoration is correct, the Old Uyghur parallel would be less close for this passage.

comments.comment: This is probably a confession text referring to the first person and reporting about teachings in the past.
We seem to have a metre of seven- and eight-syllable verses.
yel(·)ṣ(·)m can be restored to a 1.pl. Pt IV form yel(a)ṣ(a)m 'we made investigate' from the root yel- 'to investigate' (cf. wāltsaṣam 'we let ground (the grain)'; -ne then would be a locative.
āñmalāṣṣän-ne is the only reasonable separation; it can be a 3.sg. verbal form of a verbal stem āñmalāsk- which ought to underlie the abstract añmalāṣṣälñe 'sympathy'.
The word separation is unclear.
The masculine obl. plural adjective kadaliṣṣeṃ most likely derives from a loan of Skt. kadāli- 'evil' II: 18a and 36b. It is probably connected with a substantive expressing a negative notion.

comments.comment: The name Ulkāmukha in a5 points to the Ikṣvāku-jātaka, cf. and . For the Tibetan parallel, see now . Having been banned from their father's country by an intrigue, the four princes together with their sisters found the city Kapilavāstu, being counselled by the Ṛṣi Kapila. The place of the city was indicated by the Ṛṣi in the following way, according to the Tibetan parallel: "Kapila held up his golden sacrificial vase and with water pouring out of the vase, he outlined the foundation of a town. They built a town and it became known as Kapilavastu" ().
Right part of a large leaf.
This tune is known to have 10|11|10|11 (a, c: 4/6; b, d: 4/7) syllables. The form itself is a compound, see .
yartam \ has a strange spelling with ma written under the upper-part ta: yartma ; or yarnm for yarm 'measure'?
-ś at the end of the pāda is most likely part of an allative form.
The metre in this strophe seems to be different from that in the preceding metrical passage.
karāk seems to be derived from Skt. karaka- 'water container, vessel'.
Word separation is unclear.
rītāu does not look like a PPt, but like an adjective of the tallāu type; does sälyinme stand for sälyainmeṃ "from the line, border"?
The metre is unclear.
-ntsaṃts is a gen.pl. form.
kū no doubt belongs to a form from the root ku- 'to pour', the 3.sg.middle Sub kūtär 'will be poured' is the most likely restoration.
The mutilated form –rṇākā is obviously a borrowing from Sanskrit, but the restoration is unclear.

line.tr: ... still during [his] father's prosperity, he went into another world. ...
... (thought to) himself: "That I have driven [my] four guiltless sons from the country, now (I will) be ...
Dass ich [meine] vier Söhne schuldlos aus dem Lande vertrieben habe.
That I have banned [my] four sons, guiltlessly, from the country.
... after having sat in the assembly with his ministers about this matter [as motivation], (the king wants to go) to [his] four elder sons (in the city) Kapilavastu. ...
... In [the tune] (bahudantāk?) || From this glorious city of Dipāvati the great king Ikṣvāku Virūḍhaka (departed) ...
... he places it with deference in front of [his] sons beginning with (Ulkāmu)kha. The former Ṛṣis, having evoked the medita(tion)s ...
... inside me a lair of sufferings has arisen [since] I have driven them guiltlessly out of the country. They shall hear that ...
... if no one eats [her] ..., she will not bite without guilt. This one who is doing good as compensation to the good ones, is not to be restrained ...
... the good deed ... (s)he does not fail amidst the clinging [to existence]. This is the knowledge obse(rved) by the good ones.
... this is definitely known. In this city of Dipāvati through a single [blood] line the Ikṣvākuids (by) a hundred-fold (generation?) ...
... the diadem of the earth god [= Kapilavastu], being superior in splendor to every city of the worlds.
... (this speech) should be (under)stood (as taking place) in the (glor)ious city of Kapilavastu. Then going upwards the ... of the countries belonging to Śākyas ...
... being under the domain of the city of Kapilavastu 32 cities (not) comparable with the divine cities in the countries ...
... a fighting army in hundreds completely destroyed ... in ...; there (every) region(al) city installed a king ...
... they installed the ... Kṣatriyas as elders there. Thereupon also these vassal kings ... the matter ...
... they also built another 108 vassal cities. Besides (also): ...
... after having ... was decorated in the cities. They proclaimed a might without equal in delight like the one of [the city] Sudarśanā. Of king Virūḍhaka ...
.... out of impatience they impeded the power of all Jaṃbudvīpa kings. 1. Thereupon ... (the city) Kapilavastu ...
... because of the prince Rājyābhinandi these four princes (by) their own paternal Śākya (king) ...

comments.comment: To the same Jātaka belong and ; for the Tibetan parallel, see . King Ikṣvāku Virūḍhaka, after having expelled his four elder sons in order to have his youngest becoming crown pince, feels remorse and wants to visit them in the city Kapilavstu founded in the meantime by the four princes.
One may restore a form of pälskā - 'to think' in the usual phrase with the comitative of 'self'.
The metre seems to have 12-syllable pādas (7/5). At the end of the line, tāk(·) most likely belongs to a Subj./Opt. of tākā - 'to be'.
-kne no doubt belongs to a tune name. Since it seems to have 4x25 syllables (5/5/8/7), it may be bahudantāk.
We seem to have a metaphor for remorse with feminine reference (perhaps a serpent), but the details are unclear. -sa maybe belongs to a perlative form such as (entse)sa 'out of greed'.
The word separation mecurukani is not certain; however, there is a toponym mecurudi- attested in Buddhist literature, according to : s.v.

Since orotstsna is preceeded by the numeral täryāka wī '32', it has to be a mistake for the feminine plural orotstsana (maybe for orotstsnana). The following substantive ought to be a plural form of riye 'city'.
-ne ought to be a locative form.
-śśeṃ belongs to an oblique plural masculine being an attribute to kṣatryeṃ. Instead of mokoṃ, quotes a form ykoṃ-koṃ, which is certainly based on a wrong reading by Couvreur.
pi – [c](ai): perhaps pinta. ca is not certain, because the lower part is somewhat more pointy; rather [kä]?
ispek can be followed by ṣpä or cai and introduces a tune's name and stanza. The following metrical passage has a metre of 4x18 [7/7/4].

line.tr: ... this (water) over there (is seen) somehow rushing (from the top) of the Sumeru-mountain...
... (for the sake of compassion?) giving refuge (?) to the five hundred merchants...
... after having rushed down (inside) the ship, out of anger as it were ...
... in order to draw the people from the Mahāsamudra together with you ...
... may it (the ship) turn away (from ...) Having said that, (according to the wish) of the Boddhisattva Supāraga
... it turned back, it began to (sail) in the direction on the border of the ocean.
... (started) to shake. The great (Nāga-kings) beginning with Sāgara ...
... they filled up as it were the surface of the sky with divine (jewels?)
... seeing the behaviour of (ocean/monster?), (the merchants dicussed ...) their own heedlessness ...
... maelstroms (?), so frightening, kept appearing ...
... it (the hot water) jumps up high, the numerous animals will swallow us as it were ...
... looking at the Boddhisattva Supāraga with sympathetic glance ...
... (the merchants say: ||) in the apsaradarśana (tune) || 'O compassionate one, show love to all! ...
... you have freed us from bad (obstalces) before this. ...
... O you inspiring delightful speech! O constant one! O enduring one! O honourable one!
... O dear one! O noble one! Take us under your care!

line.tr: ... [The chariot driver Chandaka] seized [the horse] Kanthaka. This Kanthaka ... because of the separation from [his] master ...
... with the head letting rain burning tears, he began to (bow towards) the feet of the Bodhisattva ...
... having stretched [his] golden-colored arm [and] having put [his] hand provided with webbing on the head of Kanthaka, the (Bodhi)sattva (says) ...
[you] ought to be full of suffering and this is your animal birth. As you (pay homage?) to me because of that ...
(after) having (obtained) myself the dignity of Buddhahood, I (will) pull you out of the mud of the Saṃsara ...
… having (attained) the Buddha rank, then I will pull you out of this saṃsāra swamp … (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)
having made ... before, [the horse or the chariot driver Chandaka] began to go to [the city] Kapilavastu. Again and again he kept looking (back) desperately ...
having become weak, being disturbed, tripping, he kept going calling the Bodhisattva. Thereupon ...
... they brought. ...
they emitted (the news [of the return of the horse]) out from the city of (Kapi)lavastu far over the earth: "This is the most noble among horses."
The horse Kanthaka, having seen the garden Nyagrodhārāma, ... loudly (?) (in the) middle of ...
having seen the city of Kapilavastu, going [slowly] step by step because of suffering ...
the whole city of Kapilavastu was full of (joy). Then (in) the city of Kapilavastu (the news was heard:)
"The lord Sarvārthasiddha has turned back." Thereupon the people readily ran, ministers, princess(es), ...
"Sarvārthasiddha (is not there)." Then [a crowd of women] beginning with Gopikā Yaśodharā being confused by the sorrowful (news) ...

comments.comment: Lalitavistara, p. 231, 13-232,6

Complete left part of a leaf with the string hole, PK NS 350 makes a perfect joint on the right side. In the first line of the verso side material from another fragment seems to have been glued over the writing in some cases, which makes the reading difficult.
Information as to the provenance of the PK AS 15 fragments is entirely lost, but PK NS 350 has the expedition code DA.
The complex niyātun does not have the shape of a regular Tocharian word; one may think of a loan, perhaps referring to horse's ornamental harness.
In the complex wekwe ·rāna we can isolate wek referring to the cry of the horse. One may consider to set up an adverb wekwe "loudly". ·rāna should be the complement of the adverb ywārc.

comments.comment: The verse part maybe has the meter 4 x 15 (7/8 or 8/7).

Right part of a large leaf with part of the right margin preserved; recto and verso are unclear; there has been a small piece wrongly placed at the end of lines a 4 and b 3, it has to be turned by 45 degrees.

me is the end of the name of the purohita; the ū either also belongs to this name or is the pronoun (s)ū; telanma is most likely an error for telkanma "sacrifices". The next forms ṣeṃ raitwe cannot be correct either, ṣeṃ should belong to telkanma being the adjectival complement of raitwe; either the anusvara is mistaken, or the form raitwe is a plural.
riyaṃ is certainly the end of a plural form being the subject of the verb; maybe (plo)riyaṃ, pl. of ploriyo "musical instrument".
caranmasa is a perl.pl. of a word car* that is certainly a borrowing from Sanskrit cara- from the root car- "to move"; the precise meaning, however, remains unclear.

rāja- is the start of a color-compound borrowed from Skt. rājavarta- "multicolored", cf. TA rājavartt "id." b3 and a7. It can be restored as rājavat-yok, which is already attested in b 6, but one would rather expect rājavart*, unless the form has been borrowed via Prākrit.

The loc.pl. k[w]alyiṃne is an hapax of the kälymiye-inflection type; this separation is more likely than śk[w]alyiṃne; it may belong to the root kulā - "to recede" referring to a ritual instrument such a a strainer or filter. naś is the end of an allative form. yokaiwenta rather refers to yok 'hair' than to yoko 'drink' (note that filters are made from animal hair), cf. the magical text b5, where yokaiwenta is again used in the context of a Maṇḍala.

kaucciyaṃn(a) is the fem.pl. of an adj. kaucciye*, the meaning of this hapax remains unclear; the form maṇḍāl either has to be restored to the (yet unattested) plural maṇḍālänta (which would mean that the form is an alternant) or to an adj. derived from it.
The segmentation of k(·)ek(·)ä(–) is uncertain; it is either a nominal sentence or a verb, though the latter seems unlikely with respect to the structure of this complex.
yām most likely belongs to a form of the root yām- "to do".

parskalyisa ought to be a perl.sg. of an abstract of the type akalye/āklyi; it is based on the abstract of the subj. V stem parskalñe (with initial accent), the transfer to the akalye/āklyi-inflection may be based on an analogy by replacing the suffix -ñe with -iye; alternatively, the derivation started with the substantivized Ger. parskalye, the suffix of which was restructered as an abstract based on the akalye/āklyi-type. Note that there is at least one other form of this type attested, i.e.wikṣalyisa "through avoidence" in b 4.
khadyotänta is no doubt a loan from Skt. khadyota- “fire fly”.
nirghātänta is no doubt a loan from Skt. nirghāta- “hurricane, earthquake”.

internalComments.comment: b2-b3: “This is the way when the Buddhas have not grown in the world. Thus, in many kṛtayuga-times, those who are Bodhisattvas equipped with great power become ṛṣis in exactly such a manner.”

comments.comment: An almost complete leaf with the right margin. PK AS 16.2 and are two successive leaves.

. proposes to restore ka(lytär) instead of ka(ntär), but this is not supported by the manuscript. Note that we may have a subjunctive in future function here. In addition, it is likely that the same verb has to be assumed for the preceeding sentence, which is connected by the repetition ceṃ saimtsa : centsak saimtsa.
tusāk warñai "starting with this" means: for this reason given, but there are many others.
śūke 'juice' here refers to the divine food of the first Golden Age.

ywārc yärttoṣ, lit. "dragged in the middle" here refers to the state of division and conflict inside human society between the classes, due to greed and jealousy. The locative plural wertsyaṃne has been translated by a singular here even though it refers to the multiple ways of association between humans (family, class, etc.). It does not refer to a single, concrete assembly.

calle cannot be related to the root tälā - (thus ) for formal and semantic reasons. The complement miṣenta lit. 'fields' refers actually to the possessions of the Kṣatriyas. Now, some of them decide to renounce their assets and turn to a hermit's life. Therefore the likely meaning of calle is 'to avert, abandon, renounce'. From the formal point of view it can be an allegro form of the root kut-, cf. .
airpätte belongs to the root and here refers to a state of complete absence of worries, passions or sorrows called Ataraxia (lit. tranquillity') in the Classical philosophical tradition.

comments.comment: The meter at the beginning seems to consists of seven-syllable cola. Maybe 4 x 14; the one beginning in b3 is unclear.
Right part with the right margin, recto and verso are uncertain.
The reading lokanma is certain, one cannot restore ślokanma or sklokanma.

kaccalyasa is the perl.sg. of an action noun kaccalya, but the obl.sg. is so far known as kaccalyai. The present form is due to a mistake or to analogy. The next word yokasso has to be a form of an adj. yokassu*, according to a productive pattern in -ssu; the precise case form is uncertain, but if it is true that we have a seven-syllable meter, the nom.pl.masc. yokassoñc or obl.sg.masc. yokassont are to be preferred.
sämpāre is a 3.pl. Pt I form of a yet unattested root sämp- or sämpā -.
nal is certain; the damaged lower part looks like 〈s〉 at first glance, but the bow is far too much drawn to the left; it is rather part of a 〈ra〉 or 〈ū〉.
ppyā starts another ipt. form, which, however, cannot be one made from a root in p-, because those do not have the ipt. particle p(ä)-; the double pp is rather due to sandhi.

line.tr: ... oh my heart, now watch indeed in which way I do observe the command of the master, the Omniscient!
... the juwel (of ...) seeing the behavior of the gem with gracious eyes says: "Oh dear son, this is my body, yours
... (this) is the way of the (householder?), for whom there will be a son [and] a daughter, [who] will be his house company. If this possession ...
... because of the wish concerning (living a monastic life), for a second time in such a way you looked at me having abandoned dwelling in a household,
... I will live the life (of a monk), I will beg with the almsbowl in every house. Of which one the compassion will arise, this one will give me food.
... (is my) jewel. He (planted?) the hatred (in the earth?), but he brought ...
... in little [pieces], as it were, he will chop up my body, alive I should not bring shame on you, not my ...
... striving towards the rank of (omni)scient, then you have rejected all the lives [as lightly] as grass. For you there was no service and also no flattery (??)
... for the sake of ... then (you accepted?) to see sufferings of that sort. That [situation] vexed you so much [and] to such a degree because of our dignity.
... nevertheless those burn in hell. You (sg.) firmly taught the control of the mind, and you did not give the resolution of the heart
... of which (deeds) having obtained the (fru)it, I will not fullfill your trust to leave the house according to your Law, oh Omniscient master! I (have heard the) name (of the Buddha?)
... (blind) I will not see your city, which is monkhood in my total account. I myself for sure burned in countless hells. If indeed (I) ... you
In unzähligen Höllen bin ich bestimmt verbrannt worden.
In countless hells I have certainly been burned.

comments.comment: The text is probably metrical and seems to consist of very long lines. It is probably a confession text.
A well-preserved right part of a large leaf behind the string hole with the right and the upper margin preserved. It does not belong to the other leaves of the series PK AS 16.
Both (nau)mīye and wamer are metaphors for persons.

The complex lek(··)añña is unclear, but it cannot be a complement adjective of wamer, which is masculine; an alternative restoration for the following is (sta)r-(c)ä "is for you". sar(·)a(·)e (··)ṃ(·)e may be completed to sar(y)a(t)e (ke)ṃ(n)e "planted in the earth".

One may hesitate between reading ram no, which is more likely from the syntactic point of view and ram ot \; the latter reading entails virama position with the last sign written immediately under the second last consonant. The last word is difficult; the last consonant is certainly a t in virama position and the vowel is e, but the first may also be ṣ. Hence, a late variant ṣet (or mistake?) for the 2.sg. Imp ṣait is thinkable, but unexpected. On the other hand, pet may also be another term for "service, privilege, benefit" vel sim. that could be related to peti "± flattery", which is always attested with yarke "honor". The meaning of the passage would be that the Bodhisattva, having chosen the life as a mendicant, was derprived of wordly service. Note that pauśye usually means "service to a king, levy".

The complex cemwa should be analyzed as cem wa, wa being the particle; since there is no word ending in -cem, it seems reasonable to assume it is the nom.pl.masc. of the demonstrative pronoun sam(p). The late form cem for classical caimp is actually attested as well as the gen.pl. cempaṃts in a classical text.

The complex /// okälpauketañ can reasonably only be separated into o kälpau ke tañ, with ke being the variant of the gen. relative pronoun kete in sandhi with the following. It should refer to a preceding notion, which could have been (ok)o. The speaker refers to sins that will hinder him in reaching salvation, because of their negative effects.
We are dealing with a simile of monkhood, regarded as a city of refuge, which can be seen from afar; it cannot be reached with a feeble spirit.

comments.comment: Left part of a leaf around the string hole with the left margin; remains of horizontal and of vertical lines around the string hole are preserved.

tau is clearly readable, but cannot be a correct form; it was most likely wrongly copied from toṃ. The complex steya does rather not contain the copula ste, since we have a plural subject and the copula cannot stand at the beginning of a clause. It is more likely that steya belongs to a borrowing from Sanskrit starting with the first member of compound steya- "thief".
we should be a form of the root weñ- "to speak".
The tune name can be restored based on a4-5. It has 4 x 14 syllables (7/7).
atkwaltse is a productive adjective based on the hapax atkwal, which seems to denote some kind of negative term.
We seems to have a number of waterbird names in this passage; note that krakre is onomatopoetic, while tsaktso*/tsaktsai* shows the inflection of the okso-type.
Since it is not likely that we have the late form aymaṣṣi for añmaṣṣi here, one should restore a compound ce-ymaṣṣi "concerned with that" of the type ta-mäkte.

comments.comment: Though this should be the leaf directly following , it is difficult to understand why it starts with the third strophe of a poem in a different metre than the strophe just before the end of AS 17H. It is more likely that the leaf numbers are incorrect. The metre here has a [7/7/4] division. The following strophes have the metre 4x14 [7/7].
cakes= arwāre: because of the perl. cakes= (= cakesa), we should translate 'more readily than' v.s. rather than Pinault's "Aussi prompte[ment] qu' " ().
The segmentation warserw· – – is uncertain. If one separates warsa, this can be the perlative of war 'water' belonging to a simile. Cf. possibly warsa 'pitied' a1 and TA wras- 'suffer'.

One line of the strophe is missing, at least when one admits that a stanza has four pādas as usual. Since of the three lines that are preserved the last two seem to form a coherent whole, 4a or 4b will be missing.
yatsi: although this word starts pāda 1b, it belongs syntactically most probably to pāda 1a.
The reading is uncertain, and a form ending in -reye is otherwise unknown.
m(asa): perhaps to be restored thus. In any case, this sentence needs a finite verb, as it can hardly be a postponed subclause to the preceding sentence with plyewsa.

airpä –: the only possible restoration seems to be a form of airpätte. With poetry allows placing the attribute after the head noun, one may assume that this privative belongs to yoksa. It would refer to the unchangingly bright color of Supriya.

kau(c yāmu): After kauc we expect a form of the verb yām- as in a 6. Since the number seven ought to stand before naumyenta, it seems that there is place only for yāmu, the PPt being used as predicate. The finite preterite yamaṣṣa would be too long.
– m: The most likely restoration seems to be the distant demonstrative (sa)m.

line.tr: This is a jewel of patience for me, [and it is] strongly honoured by me: in its power standing on top of the wishes.29 We will not let it become weak, [but] we will let our own heart[s] be silent. We will not be able to be …30 in the occasions of the sorrows. (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)

comments.comment: The metre here always has the subcolon division 4+3; therefore, the last colon in 1d has to be restored to cämpem + monosyllabic (wes is the most likely) and to a monosyllabic word beginning with s and ending with a single consonant making a ligatura with the nasal of nessi. A possibilty would be sān 'enemy'.

The word separation śyetärccaṃ – kkana is very uncertain. Since the subcolon division is consistently 4+3, -kkana maybe the end of a tri-syllabic word that can be the plural of a substantive or of an adjective connected with läklenta.
The mentioning of the leaving of all the gods recalls the commonplace dramaturgical indication at the end of an act or scene.

line.tr: I wish excellence from the lord, together with …, so that we will be happy! (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)

May we see the … beings with … embodied by a trusting form. (Together) we will rejoice, out of joy my heart will float completely; or is this perfect happiness, and will [he] see him glad, trusting, and happy? (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)

comments.comment: We are at the end of a stanza with a metre of 15 syllables ([7/8] or [8/7]).

– käṣṣe is the end of an adjective being an epithet of laitke 'liana'; if the form has three syllables, we would expect in principle – kaṣṣe. However, since it has to refer to a special kind of garland used as token of welcome, it may be a loan from Sanskrit that did not conform to the usual orthographic rules. A more likely alternative is to assume another syllable and to read and restore (pässa)käṣṣe 'consisting of a garland'.

It is possible that the lacuna contained another vocative form in -ññu or -ṣṣu. One may think of kat(kär)ñe(ṣṣu) as an adjective derived from an abstract being equivalent to Skt. gambhīratā- or Skt. gambhīratva- 'profoundness, sagacity'.
The metre has 4x18 (7/7/4) syllables.

It is impossible to assume a restoration other than walo even though the large lacuna does not allow to indentify the name of the speaker. However, the following discourse makes it clear that the speaker is Supriya's father, who complains about having been abandoned by his son. We here have the usual theme of a Bodhisattva having renounced his status of royal prince.
märkāññe may also be read mär(t)kāññe 'shaving', which is found in the phrase āśc märtkāññe "shaving the head" for the notion of entering the monastic state.
A lacuna of 14 akṣaras at the end of this line.

The person greeting Supriya here belongs to the royal court (and is hence not the door warden any more), but it must be a person other than the king who speaks later and also expresses different feelings. Due to the long lacuna, it is uncertain whether this person is male or female. The discourse itself gives no clue to that.
A lacuna of 23 akṣaras at the end of this line.
The metre has 4x18 (7/7/4) syllables.
The mansucript has skwaṣṣai, which has to be a mistake for the masc. nom.pl. skwaṣṣi due to anticipation of the next word cai.
The first colon of pāda 1d has two syllables too few. Apparently, the scribe forgot a disyllabic word. Probably palsko.
The metre has 4x14 (7/7) syllables.

Pāda 1c seems to allude to a burdenful birth and difficult circumstances of the rearing of the young prince. It is possible that the mother may have even died and the prince being born nevertheless by magic was nourished by the father alone. Note the wordplay concerning 'burden', because a child is a burden to the mother while being in her belly, but here the son became a burden to the father after birth.
The verb in pāda is an optative and it ought to mean 'to obtain', but the traces on the paper do not allow a restitution (kallo)y, so that the most likely alternative would be (yanmo)y.

“My father, the king provided with skill (?) [and] wisdom, is able to live with the world, invested with the [correct] way [= dharmika-] and without equal. [5b] His angry enemy rises openly against the venerable ones. My father, the king will do the thing which should be done by me.”

line.tr: The lord may know for himself at which moment it is time to leave. (cf 128)
They may leave the company and the assembly, and get ready for insignificant farm work; I will leave.
If the seed is accumulated [lit. gathered] completely [and] as a whole by the good people, then a thousand Kṣatriya lords will stand ready towards me. (128 and p.c.)
… but show yourselves to the kings now, so that your big trouble of miscontent disappears completely! (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)
Die große Verwirrung des Unwillens wird euch restlos schwinden.
The great confusion of aversion will entirely fade within you.
He will always stand against me, holding the jewels ready; the kings that come from [their] countries all have to be turned into enemies. (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)
Erfreut durch die Gabe die Gedanken dieser Genießer!
With the gift, delight the thoughts of these receivers!

The kings of Jambudvīpa will come with many to see me; if he comes (from afar?63) and sees me, his lu64 hate is to rest. This command of mine is to be received as law, [since] the cakravartin-ship of all the omniscient kings is this way. (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)

Father king, wise (?) and provided with wisdom, [is] fit to live with the world in a way without equal; for the venerable … his (= the king’s) miscontent does not arise. The thing I have to do father king will do. (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)

comments.comment: Although this is not certain, the beginning seems to belong to a metrical passage. But after tumeṃ we have a prose sentence as introduction of the next stanza.
The metre has 4x14 [7/7] syllables. The tune name is otherwise unattested and cannot be restored.
The metre has 4x14 [7/7] syllables. The tune name is otherwise unattested and cannot be restored.
Pāda 4b has an unusual colon break.

If the reading yä is warranted, it seems impossible to restore a comitative form of any disyllabic word, which is expected after tasemane 'comparable with', because the accent does not move in the comitative. Therefore, since the reading is uncertain, one may consider to read ye; one possible restoration would be yetwempa.

The second colon of 4b lacks one syllable. The context imposes to segment wer 'hatred'. The preceding word maybe a substantive/adjective ending in -lu. One candidate would be the expected match of TA 'hostile, enemy', i.e. yaslu, though this is unattested in TB otherwise. But it would imply that the scribe did not simply forget an akṣara. A better candidate therefore is śpālu 'superior' in the sense 'extreme'.
saññauke can be an adjective or a substantive coordinated with the following word; it may be loan based on Skt. saṃjñā- 'harmony, understanding, agreement' through Middle Indic.

line.tr: ... These ones ... this great concern in making objects ... He decides to tell him: Bring the boy here! ...
Having heard (that) from Supriya, the friends ... out of love for Supriya [who] has surpassed [even] the [roy]al place with all [its] decorations to decorate ...
... which artisans whoever (are) skilled men, all (these) ... looking at this place (were) surpassed by the skillfullness of the lovely [things] one by one.

In the production of ... they (fashioned [and] built) this hall of sacrifice in order to be ornated with (objects). It has been fashioned by the god Viśvakarman as it were. This place [being] extremely
pleasant to look at, stand(ing) [there] like a miracle kept gladdening the people because of seeing the thoughts of ... Then Supriya coming from the place of his own sacifice after having seen

the ... place [that is] in a ... manner, because of the pleasantness ... having been amazed by the sweet thinking [coming] from [his] friends says in the [tune] ratikāma [lit. loving pleasure]: O worthy wor(ld), (fir)e
[and] (wate)r, who has ordered me to [have] trust in you down (on earth)? In (this Saṃsāra) the life here (is) the trust [which is] a thing pertaining to love. [1b] In the life [that I] wish

you (pl.) should be present in the future [being] better than anything. [1c] This life of mine having surpassed all the lives by thousands has been obtained from you (pl.). [1d] After having heard this the friends of Supriya
having been rejoiced, (having become firm-)minded, having been gladdened by [his] speech of solace, [and] having been comforted by [his] sweet thinking,
(having been ...) by [his] figure having a yośi wind, ... looking at Supriya with an unsatiable look to Supriyas lotus-like face ...
with respect they say: May we not be separated from the jewel of your mastery. [1a] With an indefatigable spirit (we wish to be of) service (to you)
... the wrong bodies. [1b] Or we should be always ready in (following ?) your speech [and] thinking. [1c] This great deed ...

comments.comment: Complemented to the left by PK NS 80.1 (= left most part with the string hole) and the small and much damaged PK NS 78.3 (middle part). All three are included in this entry. AS PK 17E is the largest fragment. There is a direct joint between PK NS 80.1 and PK NS 78.3 in lines a2, a3, a4, b2, b3, b5 and b6. Line a6 of PK NS 78.3 is completely lost.

The meter seems to have 12 syllables with the rhythm 5/7. About 10 akṣaras are missing in total in this line; accordingly, the metrical part ends after cai : In the following, we seems to have a comparison of Supriya with objects made by artisans such as the royal palace.
About 6 akṣaras are missing in total in this line.
About 3-4 akṣaras are missing in total in this line.
About 7 akṣaras are missing in total in this line. Border of fragment PK NS 78.3 after maṃñe.
täṅwaṃñe-palka is a verbal governing compound transposing Skt. priya-darśa- 'pleasant to look at' in much the same way as TA keṃ-pälk ‘heretic’ is a calque of Skt. mithyā-dṛṣṭika-.
The tune name ratik(ā)m* seems to be a loan from a Skt. form rati-kāma- 'loving pleasantness'. It has 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables.

takāso-ñ is a 2.pl. imperative from tākā - with the larger ending -so and cluster simplification of initial pt°; note that in b3 from the same manuscript we find the more regular form ptākas (in verse, pāda end) and in PK AS 17A a5 (in verse).
The lacuna has about 5 akṣaras, nothing is missing at the end. At the end of the line a little piece from a different fragment has been wrongly glued to this paper.
yośi-yente should be a compound, perhaps transposing a Skt. compound with a word for 'wind' as second member.
The first lacuna has about 9 akṣaras; there is a lacuna of about 12 akṣaras between the text and the restored double daṇḍa.
The tune has 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables.

line.tr: ... provided with goodness only in the (root of) virtue. (Having) seen that, th(ese peo)ple having been amazed (by the) splendor of (Supriya) they (say to each) other: (In the tune ...)

In the (pow)er (of this beautiful one?), we have (obtai)ned to see the capacity consisting of divine happiness. The thing which is right now exactly in the middle of all, this appears as an excellent mandala. [1b] And it (bestow)s an extraordinary happiness for (both) eyes
through the vision provided with nectar. [1c] Because of our goodness the human existence has become provided with fruit for us right now. [1d] Now, this speech ought to be understood

(as taking place) in the divine world (of) the Trāyastriṃśa gods. Here (and now) the god Viśvakarman says to Indra: In the [tune] p.: “By the divine chief-guardians [of the directions] it was told to me.

Listen to this! [1a] (Which is) this order [and] instruction by which all the power has been shown [lit. made]? [1b] The palace of the lord, the king of gods [is] superior in that way. [1c] I have (come?) (here towards) Supriya

[who is] comparable with that one [i.e. the palace]. [1d] (I have made?) this lions (seat) as (big) as the Sumeru mountain. [2a] With royal ornaments I have decorated his body. [2b] Whichever (happi)ness [and] (jewel)s
Mit königlichen Zierden habe ich seinen Körper geschmückt.
With royal ornaments I have adorned his body.

the former kings (of the gods) have allotted [2c], Supriya (has surpassed their) excellency [and] the capacity of that.” [2d] (After having) heard this, Indra (having) a tranquil mind [and] being rejoiced
by the coming of Viśvakarman, says: In [the tune] b.: “Bring to the jewel of a human the gem together with the [female] elephant made of jewels! [1a] These excellent, divine ornaments, I sent
them as mark of homage providing happiness. [1b] In the hardships of the (Kleśas) it makes his body inhale [the signs of] happiness immediately (?) [1c] In this forest of the (Saṃ)sāra
being tired by the sufferings, may we become without self! [1d] Thereupon Indra, (bowing to him ?), standing in front of Supriya (says): In [the tune] s.: “Sit down, oh noble one,
without hesitation on the lion's seat! [1a] Receive the excellent royal dignity without the sha(dow of hat)red, without enemies, [1c] on these four continents, on the path of the (ten) deeds. [1c]

(Since) the living beings ought to be (freed), the time has come for you to (become king??). [1d] After having ceased (to speak precisely this divine speech), Indra (says?) (to) the Trāyastriṃśa gods ...

comments.comment: The right side of a large leaf with the right margin completed to the left by PK AS 16.6.1 (left margin) and PK NS 78.2 (middle with part of the right string hole). This makes an almost complete leaf. There is a direct joint between PK AS 16.6.1 and PK NS 78.2 in lines a/b3 and a/b4 around the string hole and also between PK NS 78.2 and PK AS 17F in line a2/b5 (in line a3/b4 only one akṣara is missing). Lines a5/b2 and a6/b1 of PK NS 78.2 are lost.
In the lacuna (approx. 10 akṣaras) the tune name is missing and the beginning of the first pāda. The tune has 4x18 syllables with rhythm 7/7/4.
The tune has 4x14 syllables with rhythm 4-3/4-3. Note that the colon break falls between the compound members k(a)m(a)rttika- , -ñakte(nt)sa.
Note the spelling supryeṃ.
The hapax ṣaukār seems to be an adverb based on an abstract from the root 'to bring, offer, present', i.e. lit. 'at deliverence', 'immediately'.

The restoration of the tune name is quite certain, it has 4x18 syllables with rhythm 7/7/4. Based on the metrical analysis of this line on the recto side, only one akṣara ought to be missing in the lacuna after tumeṃ. One may restore (nmor)m(eṃ) "after having bowed" or (ce n)m(au) "bowing to him".
The tune name seems to be based on the abstract stemye "standing, stage, status" (from the root stämā - 'to stand'); note that in this text we often find tune names that reflect the situation.

line.tr: ... looking at the sky. Rain came from the height of the sky, a shower of pearls. Whoever (of) the living beings ...
... the great kings of the Nāgas, having violently evoked mutually the anger of [their] power [and] having been agitated ...
... This rain came from the top of the sky. Whichever [gem, having a] name, (beginning with) the Vaiḍūrya [lit. cat's eye], [is] desireable by the living beings, (rained down) ...
... jewelries, ornaments [and] decorations, horses, chariots [and] elephants, seats (in) [large] number ...
... the Śuddhavāsa gods, dwelling in heaven, (have been) rejoiced by the marvel done by Supriya ...
... came. To each other they told word about the Cintāmaṇi jewel [that has been] sent (by) the Bo(dhisattva) ...
... the god(s) saw ... . (In) the human world they have seen the (glory?) (of) Supriya having arisen ...
... having been ready in the wink of an eye, by the Śuddhavāsa gods (the surface?) of the heaven (is filled?) ...
... the mountains have been amazed by the accomplishment of the perfect intelligences, in that way big ...
... having been worn, others [are] blue, some [are] red, [and] amidst white ones ...
... in the sky having been ready to [pay] homage to Supriya, they have come (to) the divine worlds ...
... they (started?) to descend, like large lightning bolts falling from the sky, [like] full moons ...

pada.s:
"... of the (pro)claiming spirit, [1a] ·u ko nu ; (k)l(āwä)
ṣṣeñcai pälskontse
oh venerable one, listen to the word spoken by me concerning all the happinesses! [1b] aṣanīk(a) po skwanmaṃts ; pklyauṣ ñī reki weweñoṣ
The forest appears lovely [and] pleasant without equal. [1c] wartto lkātär täṅwaṃñe ; cäñcarñesa snai wace :

This is the place for the descent of [my] mother [and] my father, the lord. ami pātri säsweṃtse ; kārpa
llene se īke
Rivers flow ... but on the meadow with the colour of emerald. [2a] cken(t)a reskeṃ oṣṣompai ; vairuḍi-yok warsīne :
With the ... tongues ... [2b] colormeṣṣeṃ kantwaṃtsa ; s kw· talñe :

But the lotus pools with eyes of blue lotus [2c] show esteem for us uppāltsa
na lymanta no ; tsen-uppālṣeṃ eśaiṃts(a) :
ṣarpseṃ wesne ynāñmäññe ;
[and] call us to the descent. śaukentär-me kārpoś ra

But the pools provided with night-lotus, with these teeth of white lotus [3a] laugh at the joyful rainshower [and] at the encouraging (sign)s. [3b] kmutätstsana lymanta no ; kemeṃtsa ceṃ kmu
täṣṣeṃ
praśye keryeṃ kakāccoṣ ; späntauwwa (nm)i(tan)t(a) wrantsai :
Trees stand on the river-bank, having a pleasant odour, [the] divine [ones] [3c] stāna klyenträ petwesa ; cäñcre-were ñäkcyana :

[and] exhale [their] perfume [like] a lover [exhales] the love out of his body for his well-beloved." wlāskeṃ were kek(ts)eñmeṃ ; täṅwassu taṅw
laryaiśco

prose.s:
The prince Sunetra having (finished) saying this close to the forest Kusumaghana, after that the cakravartin king Supriya having (touch)ed with the hand the drums [and] the wind instruments in the (wo)od with(out) ani(mals), ... they made [their] way of descent on the bank of the pool full of blue water lilies. te ka wentsi sunetre mc(u)ṣke (ārskor)m(e)ṃ etsuwai kusumaghaṃ warttoś : tumeṃ supriye cakravārtti walo ṣarsa kerunta

pada.s: “This forest is without sound [and] fitting only for the prudent ones. [1a] wartto se ste snai klene ; maimaṃcets ka ayātoś :

Keep away from arrogance, śarwarñemeṃ päña
rkas ;
control [your] spirit [and] the senses! [1b] palskw indrinta pulāwat
These places of the good ones are not to be found in any way empty. [1c] mā toy nta kca ikenta ; krentäṃts aikri mäskeṃtär

Certainly the beasts in this place [are] tamed by prudence. lwāsa nemce ce ykene ; maimaṃtsñempa ri
ttauwwa :
The body [which is] the thirst of the whole world [= being unhappy], may I obtain [it] provided with happiness. [2a] po śaiṣṣeṃtse yokī(ye) ; (ke)kts(e)ñ källoym skwassuññai :
With an untamed spirit [it is] difficult to obtain happiness. [2b] ayātaicce palskosa ; sak käll(ālñe) (a)māskai :

s.tr: The prudent ones who have been controlled by body, speech and spirit, [2c] these ones rejoice in this place 'like the bee [Skt. Silimukha-] among the flowers.

Here the cakravartin king Supriya in the company of thousand sons, and of those [who are] kings [and] ministers on the four continents ... tane cakravārtti wal(o) supr(i)ye yaltse sesū
wampa kUse ṣ(pä) śt(w)āra dvipan(ma)ne lā«ṃ»c amācäntañ l·ī

Trees grow [lit. stand] by the river-bank, lovely smelling [ones], divine [ones] ...

The metre has 4x14 [7/7] syllables.
Either the scribe forgot a stanza or wrote the wrong strophe number.

The reading yo śukecce is certain. But since there is no word ending in -yo that fits here and since śuketstse 'juicy' does not make sense as attribute of palsko, we assume sandhi, even though this is a prose passage.

internalComments.comment: and the life did not part from my body!

prose.s:
Looking at Supriya, the sister of Priya, called Priyaratī, says to Somyaratī: supriyeṃ lkāskemane priyentse ṣer priyarati ñem somyaratiṃ
ś weṣṣäṃ
in [the tune] yakwe: || yakwene ||

pada.s: “Look now at this one, the ornament of every birth, oh loveable one! yetwe po cmeltse ; palkas-ne nai täṅwaṃñai :
This one distinguishes himself like the moon among the stars. ṣeske wākṣtär se ; śirinne ra meṃ-ñäkte :

By [his] manner [and] gesture having surpassed all the others. yakne pi(k)ārsa ; ṣeṣṣīrku
po alyeṅkäṃ :
He [= Supriya] has gone away with the happiness because of the realisation of [his] wish.” spärkau sakämpa ; akālkäntse knelñesa :

prose.s:
Here Sumanā pointing at Supriya with a blue lotus says to Priyasundarī: tane sumana tseññai uppāltsa supriyeṃ ṣärpsem(a)ne priya
sundariṃś weṣṣäṃ
in [the tune] käryorttaññe. || käryortaṃñen(e) ||

pada.s: "Your mind, full of nectar, floats out of joy! palsko pluṣañ-c nai ; katkauñaisa śuketstse :
The jewel of a human has manifested himself far from me. naumye śaumoṣṣe ; ñśameṃ pākri tatākau (:)

You rejoice [and] you are satiated about that because of the blue lotus of his beauty. k(ā)cc(ä)t soyast te ;
c(w)ī ersnāṣṣai pad(u)mtsa :
He is glad of it [= the beauty] like the bee [Skt. śilīmukha-] among the flowers. cesa plontotär ; śilimuk ra pyāpyaiṃn(e)

Like a golden forest this one gleams out of grace, having surpassed all the deli(cate) (v)eṣ(ṭ)aṇā flowers, through [his] brilliance [which has] outshone [even] the lotuses. w(a)rt(t)o ysāṃññe ra ; cäñcarñesa se palkäṃ :
Who could then exist [who] would [ever] be satiated by this view? kUs(e) no su tākoy ; ce lkālñesa soyi nta :

prose.s: Then Priyasundarī ... says to (Sumanā): tumeṃ priy(a)sundari (sumanai)ś weṣṣäṃ

in [the tune] Prasenajit: ||
prasenajittsa ||

pada.s: "Oh loveable one, is it really that what you have said in your place? tenak teṃ ste täṅwaña ; kUce (t)we wñāsta ṣañ ykene :
This creates extreme happiness for me through the manners provided with [correct] manner. sak wakīce tanmäṣṣä-ñ ; yäkneso(n)tä(ṃ) y(ä)kn(e)nts(a) :

How is [it that] the happiness [that is] provided with nectar [exists and] just so even the sufferings? mäkte sa(k) ste śu
ketstse ; mäntak rano läklenta :
By incessant memory this [question] is not kept away from my thinking. epyācñesa snai kärstau ; mā tw arṣṣītär-ñ pälskormeṃ :

(All) my manners [of acting and my] gestures stand constantly before my eyes indeed. klyentär-ñ yneś ka ṣekaññe ; (po) ñī yakni
pikārnta :
May life turn my desire [and] inclination precisely towards death at that moment! śaul aiwītär-ñ ceU preke ; srukalñeś ka ṣ ñyās rmamñe :
My [desire] has bowed to this ability ce yātalñeś namtsate-ñ ;

aand the life will not part from my body! mā ṣp«†ä» śaul lac
ñī kektseñmeṃ :
Now I rejoice with happiness like a sparrow [that has] reached a cloud. ñake saksa pl(o)ntomar ; tarkär yainmu ṣparāy ra

prose.s:
Here Supriya entered in deep reflexion [and] only by himself says: tane supriye palskalñene maiyyācce yaipu (ṣa)ñ añmämpa ka
(weṣṣä)ṃ
"Which has been the refuge and (protecti)on of the city? k(Us)e sai(m) (wast)e tāka rī(ntse)
They [= the people of the city] do not go outside in my presence ñīśam(p)a parna mā lnaskeṃ
[and] they neglect [what has been] ordered by the lord; säsweṃtsa watkai pr(u)kseṃtär
they peer at us only through the gaps [in the windows/doors coverings]. ts(r)oriṃtsa ka perkentär-me
[Are they] really (not) desirous (to come together) with me? (mā) t(n)e ñās(s)oñc ñīśam(p)a (ṣe)

line.tr: Look at the ornament of all [re]birth, o love! (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)
Your mind, full of savour, [seems to] float out of joy! (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)

The meter is unclear, but the last pāda has 15 syllables with the division 8/7. It cannot, however, be a tune of the known shape 20|22|10|15, since the last colon of 1c also seems to have seven syllables.
The meter is 4x12 (5/7).
The meter is 4x12 (5/7).

The meter has 14 syllables (7/7), but very unusually we have eight pādas per stanza if the numbering and punctuation are accurate. Since usually stanzas have four pādas, one may suppose that the scribe miscopied two stanzas. Note that the other occurrences so far of this tune name do not allow for a solution. Note in addition that this tune name always appear in the perlative instead of the locative.

prose.s:
"(Are they really not desirous to come together with me)?
(śamtsi)

Now in order to be (loved) here, through other streets I will try to [get to] know the cause of the fact that the streets in [great] number are empty." ñ(a)k(e) omt(e) (täṅ)w(aṃ)tsi (a)lyeṅkä(ṃ) nau(ntaintsa) (wänta)rentse ṣarm rītamar aistsi aikari k(e)śn(e) n(au)nt(aiṃ) sk(e)nt(e) •

Thereupon Supriya sought from the king the permission to go by other streets. tum(eṃ) supr(i)y(e) l(ān)tämeṃ ā(rtalñe) (ya)
skastär alyeṅkäṃ nauntaintsa yatsi ||
Here he [= the king] asked Supriya: tane su(p)ri(yeṃ) (p)r(e)kṣäṃ
"Why, oh noble one, are you so distracted? kā twe klyomai allek-pälsko taisa mäsketar
Have you, by chance, had anything happening to you that is not suitable to your mind? mai ksa tane pälskontse mā ayāto tāka-c

Tell it to me!"
t(e) ñī pokse ||
Thereupon Supriya says to the king: tumeṃ supriye lāntäś weṣṣäṃ
“Everything suits me on the part of the lord. po ñī ayāto säsweṃnmeṃ ste
I am desirous to see living beings: onolmeṃ lkātsi añmasu ne(sau)

This does not presuppose in any way pleasure for myself. mā te kca añmantse
wīna-yparwe
I have expressed [lit. made] the wish towards the lord to go through the[se] streets.” säs(we)näś akālk yamaṣamai nauntaiṃtsa yatsi •
The king says: walo weṣṣäṃ
“In every way, this will suit (me).” po-yäknesa ayāto t(āka-ñ) ||

Thereupon Supriya goes through the streets. tumeṃ suppri
ye nauntaintsa yaṃ •
Then some people from this city peered only through [small] gaps [in the window/door coverings], tumeṃ tāU rīṣṣi śāmna ṣemi tsrorīntsa ka perśīye«ṃ»trä
but did not go outside. mā parna lännaṣyeṃ •

weṣṣäṃ

pada.s: “Will the great king consent to explain this fact completely what is the cause here? wrotse walo arccaṃtär ; ce w(ä)nta(r)e po āksi ; k(U)se ṣarm tane :
By the pain of hunger, they have been terribly stricken; kestaṣṣe ceU laklesa ; (prā)kre ṣeyeṃ memīyo(ṣ) ;

this has left them.
(s)ū w(i)kā-me :

ne yärṣāmai ; ce akālk ñiś säswenäś ; snay emprukṣai :

lñesa ñīś rano ; skw(aṃ)ts(e) s(war)eṃ ekalymi ; yänmoym plānto :

comments.comment: The text has many misspellings that seem to be due to unattentive copying.

PK NS 77.2 (left) and PK AS 17K make a perfect joint in lines 3, 4 and 5 and with only one or two missing akṣara in lines 1, 2 and 6 giving an almost complete leaf. On the left margin of the little fragment one sees the top of the number 100. Note that NS 77.1 and NS 77.2 are fragments of two different leaves.
The metre seems to consist of 14-syllable pādas.

The reading cä seems certain, but this has to be due to a copying error for ceṃ. The reading märskoṣṣäṃ is also certain, but so far there is no root märsk- with a PPt märskau. Therefore one may consider that it is a misspelling for pärskoṣṣäṃ, which was triggered by previous märkartsana.
The reading tärkameṃ is safe (for tärkarmeṃ).

Usually, ersna ‘form, beauty' is a plurale tantum, but singular reference is in this text actually confirmed by ersna lac in a6. The singular is no doubt due to the princess being viewed as personification of beauty. There is probably an allegorical component, as in other Buddhist (and Jaina) dramas.

In this list of musical instruments we expect a string instrument beside drum, conch, and flute. The form k(n)er* would be an old borrowing of Skt. kiṃnarī which designates a kind of lute found in Kuchean wall paintings; see .
Pāda 1b has one syllable too much, which can be fixed by counted tättālñesa as a three-syllable word with syncope of ä.

line.tr: Der Mönch, der Wertgegenstände wie Gold, Silber usw. eigenhändig annimmt, muss diese Wertgegenstände zurückgeben.
The monk who accepts valuables like gold, silver etc. with [his] own hands must give back these valuables.
Welcher Mönch auf vielfache Weise (mit) Wertgegenständen Kauf [und] Verkauf betreibt, [von dem] sollen die Wertgegenstände zurückgegeben werden.
Which[ever] monk conducts buying [and] selling (with) valuables in manifold ways, [by him] the valuables shall be given back.
If you don't give away the mantle, we will hang you up by your hair.
[Wenn] du den Mantel nicht zurückbringst, werden wir dich am Haupthaar aufhängen.
If you do not bring back the cloak, we will hang you up by the hair.

comments.comment: For a detailed commentary, see .

kraupäṣṣa, 3rd sg. act. of the causative preterit (IV) of kraup- 'to gather, amass', in the context of to 'assemble, reunite', thus 'to convene, cause to unite'. Note the accent of the causative stem on the first syllable, from whence -ä- (unstressed) in the second syllable. It must be noted, by the way, that the action noun kraupe (A krop) 'mass, troop' is also used as a translation from Skt. saṃgha- in the sense of 'congregation'.
śikṣapāt (A śikṣāpat), obl. (= nom.) sg. of a loan word from Skt. śikṣāpada- 'precept, rule', relating to morality.

śānmya, 3rd sg. act. of the causative preterit (II) of śänm- 'to bind', next to the present tense (X), 3rd sg. middle śānmästar. Since it has a rule as direct object, this verb means 'to firmly establish, to decree'.
aletstsai, obl. sg. of aletstsa, feminine of the adjective aletstse 'peculiar, unrelated'; this term is the equivalent of Skt. ajñāti- (or ajñātikā-) 'unrelated' in the Vinaya.

yākwa, obl. (= nom.) pl. of yok (genus alternans) 'pelage, fleece', from whence 'wool' of certain animals; translation from Skt. eḍaka-loman-, pl. in the Vinaya, 'sheep fleece, goat fleece', the reference of the noun eḍaka- (Pāli eḷaka-) not being limited to the former references only, but encompassing all the small livestock that produce wool.

to yākwa by sandhi for toy yākwa. Also to be restored to toy (, ) before naumiyenta: nom. pl. fem. of the demonstrative seṃ, fem. sāṃ, with anaphoric value, differentiated from the indirect pl. fem. toyna. The reduction of the geminate in sandhi (in toy yākwa) is not unknown in this manuscript; cf. further down sānk kraupäṣṣa reduced to sānkraupäṣṣa (, a2, b2).

tärkanallona, nom. (= obl.) pl. fem. of tärkanalle, gerund (I) of necessity from the present stem (VI) as in tärk- (= A) 'to let go, to abandon'. The combination of this verb with the adverb päst translates Skt. niḥ-sṛj- 'to abandon': päst tärkanalle serves as a translation of the term niḥsargika- 'who needs to be abandoned'.

ṣaḍvarginta, nom. pl. of ṣaḍvargi, from ṣaḍvargiya-, an intermediate form (partially from Prākrit, cf. Pāli chabbaggiya-) for ṣaḍvargika- or ṣaḍvārgika- ('belonging to the group of six'), denomination of a particular group of disciplines of the Buddha who attempt to liberate themselves from his teachings and moral rules.

wmera, obl. (= nom.) pl. of wamer (A wmār), masc. 'jewel, jewelry' (Skt. maṇi-). This word, as is naumiye 'jewel' further down, is actually the equivalent of Skt. rūpya- 'silver/money', in the sense of its mercantile value, which includes silver money, but also noble metals (gold, silver) and gems. The term used in the Chinese version (cf. ) is specifically băo 'precious object, treasure, jewel, jewellery' and secondarily 'money (in terms of hard cash)'.

tanāpati, nom. pl. of tanāpat, masc., borrowed from Skt. dānapati- (> *tānapat) with a transfer to the most frequent declension of the masculine forms; literally 'master of donation', or 'giver, benefactor', term for 'generous layperson'.

ṣañtsa, perlative of the reflexive possessive ṣañ. The parallel text : a1 has ṣañ ṣarsa 'with his own hand', which literally translates Skt. svahastam of the Vinaya. It is not very likely that the editor simply forgot the word ṣar 'hand'. The phonetic development (*ṣäñ-sā > *ṣántsa > ṣañtsa restituteded after ṣañ) is similar to that of other forms of the perlative sg.: kektseñtsa (of kektseñe “body”, obl. sg. kektseñ), meñtsa (of meñe 'month', obl. sg. meñ): it is definitely a form of ṣañ 'its/his/hers', nominalised to the sense of 'oneself', and broadly translating svahastam as 'of one’s own, through oneself'.

pito, masc., obl. (= nom.) sg., 'price, cost', probably borrowed from Middle Iranian, cf. Khotanese pīha- 'price'. Even though the noun karyor (A kuryar) would be able to cover the entirety of business, its association in a conceptual pair with pito 'price' suggests that the two terms are complementary: since pito 'price', implies 'of sale', karyor is therefore restrained to the sense of buying, and it is the binomial relationship in its entirety that designates business, following the example of Skr. kraya-vikrayaḥ 'buying [and]selling' = 'business', as a key word of rule NP20 (cf. ). yamaṣyenträ, 3rd pl. mid. of the imperfect, from the present stem (IX) yamáṣṣä- of yām- (= A) 'make'; from the same stem, see further down the present tense form, 3rd sg. mid. yamasträ (b1). The version of has this verb in the same phrase but with two additional terms: karyor pito misko ailñe yamaṣyenträ (a2) 'they were buying, selling, exchanging and giving'. The preliminary narration to rule NP 19 is very short in the Sanskrit version (cf. ): the examined cases, complete with commentary and casuistry, cover traffic of all sorts of items and objects of value, produced or not, no matter of what origin.

kattākets, for kattākents or kattākeṃts, gen. pl. of kattāke (A kātäk), masc. 'householder', indirect loan from Skt. gṛhastha-: the first intermediary is, in Gāndhārī, ghahaṭha-, borrowed into ancient Khotanese, from whence the drop of the intervocalic aspirant (> *ghaaṭha-), contraction, and addition of the frequent suffix -ka, thus *ggāṭha-ka- (at this point borrowed into Common Tocharian >*kāttākoe), leading to Khotanese ggāṭhaa-.
naissargī is a hypercorrect rendering of the borrowing from Buddhist Skt. naiḥsargiya- for correct naiḥsargika-

ate, adv. of distance; in spite of the superficial resemblance, this Tocharian word is originally independent of Skt. atas 'from there, after this, then' (serving also as ablative of the pronoun idam) : Toch. A atas, which was considered as its equivalent ( and 162) is a phantom word, which reads anas and has a totally different meaning.

The sign below the correction cross may either be [t]e or [ts]e. Neither form makes sense in the text, unless somebody wanted to correct upanandi into the alternative genitive upanandentse; note that in a proper name the genitive in -i is more correct.

b3 laṅkäm-c, 1st pl. act. of the subjunctive (I) of läṅk- (= A) 'hang, suspend', followed by the suffixed pronoun of the 2nd person singular. In the version of : b1, the punishment seems less severe: lyutem-cä, with the same suffixed pronoun, 1st pl. act. of the subjunctive (II) of lut- (= A) 'to distance oneself, to chase'. This part of the narration is lost in the Sanskrit text.

śrāddheṃ, obl. pl. (= sg.) of śrāddhe, masc., loan word from Skt. śrāddha- 'believing, faithful' ; parallel loan of the privative aśrāddha-, from whence the allative pl. aśrāddheṃśc, correct in : b2, simplified here as aśrāddheś. These two terms need to be understood as collectives. The version of adds poś, allative of po, masc., in the sense of 'whoever, a random person'.
śrāddheṃ is oblique plural and the next word stands for all.pl. aśrāddheṃśc, which is confirmed by the parallel THT 337 b2.

comments.comment: There are at least two late forms: stare (a2), śitkāre (b2) for śätkāre. stare is used in direct speech, and it is combined with a preterite participle that may reflect colloquial usage.

The compounds kaucū-wär 'upstream' and ñoru-wär 'downstream' contain a prop vowel before the second member beginning with w-, which has to be accented. This recalls the case of 'life long', which is likewise attested in two late manuscripts (for the date see and 222).

The borrowed adjective devadattapakṣike shows masculine agreement with the feminine pl. substantive aśiyana in all instances; this is usually a characteristic of verse due to metrical constraints. It may be a syntactic behavior of colloquial styles.
An almost complete leaf, the right margin is lost, damaged above the string hole.

Even though this leaf belongs to the same manuscript as , the scribe must have been different. The ductus is just slighly different, but there are some deviating characteristics: the use of the virāma dot after -r and the consonant sandhi sāṅ= kraupäṣṣa, where the other scribe spells sāṅk kraupäṣṣa.

Instead of nand(a)k(e) one may as well restore nand(e) and the particle k(a). Actually, the Chinese parallels cannot help to decide this issue because the monk in question is named Nanda in the Sarvāstivādin version and Nandaka in the Mūlasarvāstivādin version.
sa[ṃ]manit The anusvāra is far from being certain since the paper is damaged.

One may hesitate about the interpretation of the perlative wīnasa. According to , it is constructed with alyek as complement of comparision, hence a translation "their action different from mere distraction". But it is more likely that we have a perlative of cause referring to the fun enjoyed by the monks and nuns, which is regarded as a scandal by the local population. This seems to be confirmed by the Chinese parallel as translated by . As a consequence, alyek 'other, different' here means 'outside of proper behavior, outrageous'.

comments.comment: The fragments of the PK AS 19 series (19.1-19.22) all belong to the same manuscript. The recto and verso cannot be determined with full certainty. On the left margin of one side there is a trace that rather belongs to the imprint of another leaf than being a leaf number. Furthermore, this trace does not exhibit the characteristics of a number. On the other side there are faint traces of a leaf number. The fragment is the left half of a leaf comprising the string hole. The string hole interrupts the third line. On the right end a small piece of another leaf has accidentally been joined to the manuscript.
The form kaussi is the infinitive of the Kausativ of the verb ku- 'to pour'. This line falsifies the meaning 'weapon' for the word tsarako as given by .

The form yāmne looks as the locative singular of a noun yām which is so far unknown. This interpretation seems more likely than assuming an oblique dual. In any case the reading 〈yā〉 is safe by contrast with the alternative reading 〈yo〉. We may mention the possibility of interpreting yām* as the root noun of the root yām- 'to do, to make' meaning something like 'doing, action'.
We propose to restore the plural of the abstract kärtsauñe as the basis of the following ṣṣe-adjective, but it remains to be confirmed by a parallel text.

Apparently there seems to be an anusvara upon 〈ṣṣe〉, but it would be at variance with the syntax since this adjective is to be constructed with śūke. Therefore it is more likely that this is a stain on the leaf. In addition, It does not comply with the usual form of the anusvara in this ductus.

The leaf number which is identifiable on the verso side is 81. It exhibits the same kind of damage as PK AS 19.5 (M 504.5). The string hole interrupts the third line.

The manuscript has prukäṣṣälle which would be the Antigrundverb of the root pruk- 'to neglect'. However, this would not make sense with malkwer 'milk'. It is thus better to view it as a scribal mistake for prutkäṣṣälle belonging to the Kausativ of the root prutk- 'to fill up'.

comments.comment: The fragments of the PK AS 19 series (19.1-19.22) all belong to the same manuscript. This is a complete but damaged leaf. There is no trace of a leaf number. The string hole interrupts the third line. This large fragment consists of two parts that have not been joined consistently. In the present disposition one could believe that the two main parts are joined perfectly, but actually there is gap of approximately one akṣara between the two parts. At the right end of the preliminary verso there are remnants of akṣaras of another leaf. The latter are bigger than the ones found on this fragment.
After ṣale the reading tseṇku is almost certain, but this form is of course not correct. One may tentatively propose a scribal error for the regular preterite participle tsetseṇku.

comments.comment: The fragments of the PK AS 19 series (19.1-19.22) all belong to the same manuscript. This is an almost complete fragment including the string hole which interrupts line 3. The leaf number is 80. The fragment is quite damaged on the right side. One line on each side is hardly legible because of imprints by akṣaras from another leaf.
There are only illegible remnants of akṣaras on this line.

The form uttaragaurapäṣṣe is an adjective derived from uttaragaurap-* which obviously is a borrowing from Sanskrit. The best connection would be with Skt. Uttarakaurava- 'inhabiting the continent Uttarakuru- 123a. This implies of course wrong sankritization of the source. The form kraitara has to be the first member of a compound ending in rup- 'face'. It looks as an Indo-Aryan word, but no plausible source has been found so far.
In this line a piece of paper has wrongly been joined after taṣṣallona. It seems that the part it belongs to the next line after 〈pal〉 where it would fit perfectly giving the phrase palsko aśalle.
The form kosraittse clearly shows a Tocharian suffix. The derivational base, however, is unknown so far.
There are only illegible remnants of akṣaras on this line.

comments.comment: The fragments of the PK AS 19 series (19.1-19.22) all belong to the same manuscript. The fragment is the left part of a leaf including the string hole which interrupts the third line. In the present condition of preservation there are two smaller pieces that can be attached to the bottom left and the right margin. The latter piece is quite damaged and exhibits imprints of akṣaras from other leaves.

The vocalism of the akṣara 〈va〉 after 〈bha〉 is impossible to determine. If it is 〈vi〉, one may consider to connect with Skt. bhaviṣya-, for instance in the compound bhaviṣya-jagat-karṇadhāra- 'der zukünftige Steuermann der Welt' ( 3: 287a). Alternatively, one can restore 〈vau〉 and connect it with Skt. bhavaugha- 'die Flut des Werdens' ( 3: 287b).
There 13 illegible akṣaras at the end of this line.
There are only illegible remnants of akṣaras on this line.

The reading wikenträ is certain, however, the only conceivable subject is the demonstrative pronoun in the singular. Therefore we may consider that it is due to a scribal error for wiketrä. The form ysā- can be the beginning of the derived adjective of ysāṣṣe 'golden'. Alternatively, it can be the first member of the compound ysā-yok 'golden color'.
The form vājira probably belongs to the loan of a Sanskrit compound beginning with vajra- 'diamond'.
